On June 9th the SMART meeting will present a workshop on "Effective Use of Introductions and Referrals for Increased Business"

During this workshop, you will learn:

·  Difference of  asking for introductions and referrals

·  How you can leverage the SMART network to expand your own network

·  How to leverage your own customer base for introductions or referrals

In addition to the workshop segment, our meetings also highlight a member’s specific business as well as an educational spotlight from one of our members.

Come join us. Invest an hour and 15 minutes of your time to help you expand your business results.

 Networking SMART

     

Strategic Marketing Advisory Referral Team

 

We are seeking committed, contributing members to join

  

A Distinctively Different Networking Approach

For New Business Development and Management

 

Our creative, resourceful networking process can help you

Develop Significant Business Opportunities!

<a href="https://www.facebook.com/pages/Networking-Smart/155803897852209?ref=nf"></a>

How is Networking SMART “Distinctively Different”?

 We are a cohesive group of accomplished professionals

dedicated to contributing to the success of our members by providing:

 

-  Dynamic, Interactive Meetings

-  Actionable Business Generating Practices

-  Business Advisory Assistance and Referrals

-  An Open, Shared, Mastermind and Mentoring Forum

-  Results Driven Business Exchange and Discussions

-  Expertise Shared by Invited Guest Speakers

-  Social/Professional Network Sharing and Integration

-  Rewarding Activity and Commitment with Local Charitable Services

-  Convenient Time to Meet, 7:45 – 9:00 AM  

If you wish to augment your existing networking and referral efforts; or have found a less than satisfying experience with traditional Networking efforts; and interested to learn more about the networking SMART; approach, we invite you to our next meeting dedicated to your consideration as a potential new member. Learn how we assist with building your brand and developing new business through supportive relationships.

 

Ardito, Toscano & McCollum, PC, CPA

40 Bayfield Dr.

North Andover, MA  01845

results.description:
*** NOT Free Conference. You'll have to register with IEEE, the organizers of the conference to attend  - its about $485 per person or $285 for students.***

Wearables are all about sensors. Join this event to learn more about Body Sensor Networks!

From the event description:

The availability of small, low-cost networked sensors combined with advanced signal processing and information extraction is driving a revolution in physiological monitoring and intervention. Body Sensor Networks (BSN) are enabling technologies for precision healthcare, enhanced sports and fitness training, novel life- style monitoring, and individualized security.The 12th International Conference on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks (BSN 2015) will address BSN research and offer participants a unique forum to discuss the key issues and innovative solutions for sensors, communications, algorithms, systems, and applications. The conference features numerous invited lectures by leading academic researchers and industrial experts. On the days before and after the conference, tutorials will be presented, detailing and demonstrating BSN technologies from sensor networks to the algorithms that employ them
results.how_to_find_us: Check with IEEE, you'll need a ticket to attend.
results.name: IEEE Body Sensor Networks Conference 2015 (not free)

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Tuesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

You are cordially invited to join us for a symposium on virus quantification on Tuesday, June 9 from 1pm-6pm at the Joseph B. Martin Conference Center at the Harvard Medical School in Boston, Massachusetts.

Agenda:
•1pm – 1:15pm: Michael Olszowy, Chief Technology Officer, ViroCyt - Welcome
•1:15pm – 2pm: Christopher Kemp, President, Kempbio - Optimizing Virus-Based Expression Systems
•2pm – 2:45pm: Daniel Vellom, Senior Director, Global Technology and Innovation, Sanofi Pasteur Biologics - Accelerating Viral Vaccine Development with the ViroCyt Virus Counter

results.description:
**UPDATE: The hearing has been moved to Gardner Auditorium.  If possible, come early and attend a rally happening at 12:30 (more below).**

One of the ways to fight for racial justice is to support changes in the laws.  This hearing is an important one, and the more people who show up, the better.  From Jobs Not Jails:


"...we need your help to stop $2 billion worth of prison construction in Massachusetts. Our mission is to re-direct those funds into generating good jobs for people in low-income, high-crime neighborhoods. The Justice Reinvestment Act is a promising first step in changing the criminal justice system."

If you are planning to go, please sign up with Jobs Not Jails so they can keep you updated: http://org2.salsalabs.com/o/6220/c/1559/p/dia/action3/common/public/index.sjs?action_KEY=20324

You can also sign up and invite friends via Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/927358500620699/


Schedule of events: 

12:00: Recommended arrival time, to give you plenty of time to get into the State House and through security and up to the third floor.


12:30: Rally at 3rd floor in front on House Chamber and Room 332

12:45 Press Conference in Senate Reading Room, inside Senate Chamber on the third floor

1:00 Judiciary Committee hearing in Gardner Auditorium


***Note: This meetup will NOT count toward the six month attendance requirement of some of our meetups, as we do not expect to be engaging in a conversation together.***
results.name: Attend Justice Reinvestment Act Hearing to help change the system!

results.description:
Did you know 85 Fortune 100 companies use Atlassian software to help them innovate? That’s why Herzum is dedicating an event to show you how large companies depend on enterprise-grade performance from JIRA, Confluence and Stash. Larger companies use Atlassian products in completely different ways from startups and small businesses. They still demand the same benefits, and features that have made Atlassian a key player in over 38,000 companies worldide, but they need even more availability, scalability, and performance, as well as specific best practices for an enterprise-grade adoption. Learn from the Platinum Expertise at Herzum to discover how the Atlassian Tools can scale to generate productivity in every department of your enterprise.

If you’re interested in scaling Atlassian to new heights, don’t miss our Boston event. You’ll learn how companies like Pfizer, Citi, Cisco, LinkedIn and NASA use Atlassian Enterprise to do big, amazing things like:

+ Adopting Atlassian products as high-availability, high-performance systems.
+ Scaling capacity quickly by deploying Atlassian on-premise and using clustering and distributed loads.
+ Utilising Atlassian Enterprise services, including premier 24/7 support and Technical Account Management to take advantage of the fastest SLAs available.
+ Adapting Atlassian Data Center editions into your shared services environment by incorporating governance and best practice.

Join us for food and drink while we learn how Atlassian Enterprise can help you scale to new heights!
results.name: Scaling Atlassian in the Enterprise

Hillview Golf Course Pro Chris Carter has offered us 4 tee times at 5:15 pm starting the first week in May through the end of August.    I will post this weekly during the season and accept 16 members plus a waitlist.    The 9 hole fee is $21 and golf carts are $8, although this is a very walkable course.  If for any reason you need to cancel out, please do so 24 hours ahead of time. This  allows the  waitlist members  time to fill your spot. 


The HIllview Pro shop does  handicaps for members who would like this.You can post your score at HIllview Pro shop or online for $50 for the season.   Hillview offers lessons for those interested as well a  driving range.  I will make plans at a local restaurant for the "19th" hole and update later.

Please check out the website for further information at http://www.hillviewgc.com

UPDATE: .After a meeting of our Board, and in consideration of our ASGA members,  it was decided to  open this event  to official ASGA members initially, then to meetup members.  ASGA members pay $79 a year for membership.  Any non-ASGA members will incur a surcharge of $5 each week, payable before you golf for that day.  Any non-ASGA member  may become a member by going to www.singlesgolf.com and click 'join' thereby avoiding the surcharge.

Any questions, please contact me by clicking on my profile and then the word 'message' in order to send a private email.

results.description:
A coming of age comedy/drama for the post hip hop generation. Malcolm is a geek, carefully surviving life in The Bottoms, a tough neighborhood in Inglewood, CA filled gangsters and drugs dealers, while juggling his senior year of college applications, interviews and the SAT. His dream is to attend Harvard. A chance invitation to a big underground party leads Malcolm and his friends into a, only in Los Angeles, gritty adventure filed with offbeat characters and bad choices. If Malcolm can persevere, he'll go from being a geek, to being dope, to ultimately being himself.

CoFoundersLab Matchup Boston is aimed at helping entrepreneurs find co-founders, advisers & interns and to build strong, core startup teams.

Get started networking now with a potential core team member by creating a free profile on CoFoundersLab.com.

Agenda  
6:00: Entrepreneur Check-In 
6:15 - 6:45: Brief Intro from CoFoundersLab 
6:45 - 7:15: Round Table Intros 
7:15 - 8:30: General Networking 
8:30: End of Matchup 

Public Transportation: We are easily accessible from South Station on the Silver Line. We are located on the Silver Line 2 at the "Building 21 Marine Industrial Park" stop.
Parking: If you will be driving to the office here are the options for parking.
Visitor Parking: There are limited spaces available in front of 21 Drydock Ave (1.5 hours max)
Metered Parking: There are some metered spaces along Drydock Ave (2 hours max)
Parking Garage: There is a parking garage at 12 Drydock Ave, just across from the Design Center

CoFoundersLab Pro Members - Attend this event for FREE! Click here to learn more. 

Interested in sponsoring this event? Please submit this Sponsorship Application.


***To increase your chances of finding someone, please be sure to:

• Create a free profile on CoFoundersLab.com & add “CoFoundersLab Matchup Boston” to your profile. Go to My Profile > Events > CoFoundersLab Matchup.

• Browse CoFoundersLab.com for other entrepreneurs by filtering in the Advanced Search under Community Affiliation > Events > CoFoundersLab Matchup - Boston.

• Download the free CoFoundersLab mobile app in the iTunes app store. Now available on Google Play! </a>

• Share this event on your social channels to help get the word out. Your next core team member may be in your networks! 

Suggested tweet:

I'm building my core #startup team @CoFoundersLab Matchup #Boston TUE 6/9 6pm @MassChallenge! Join me: http://ow.ly/rSNBS

>>> <a href="http://ctt.ec/H6o9a">Click to Tweet!

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda:

**********************************

Eric Neumann, Ph.D.

Using Category Theory to get more out of Linked Data: Data integrity, migration, ontology alignment, query formalisms, logical inference, and de novo concept generation

Category Theory (CT) has been around for over half a century, and has been quite successful in areas of pure mathematics and modern physics. A component of Abstract Algebra, CT strives to find powerful generalizations and proofs that encompass logic, mathematics, and topology. More recently it is being applied to many forms of logic and semantic problems. Recent work by David Spivak on “Categorical Theory for Scientists” and “ Categorical Databases” has opened up interesting new ways to applying CT to many kinds of data query and analytic applications. All of logic (FOL, HOL, boolean, Heyting algebra, subclassifiers) is within the realm of CT, but it can be used to map data models from one system to another (ontology alignment and data migration), as well as generate new constructs (cartesian products). A key feature identified by Spivak is that RDF can be described in CT as a Grothendieck Construction, representing both typed set values and relations (fundamental elements of CT), thereby preserving data meaning (graph structure) throughout information processes. 

 

Dr. Neumann is Vice President of Knowledge Informatics at Foundation Medicine, where he is responsible for organizing FMI’s knowledge assets. He is a recognized world expert in semantic information and data modeling for life sciences, and has worked on many information initiatives for the pharmaceutical and life sciences, including the W3C Semantic Web Healthcare and Life Science Interest Group (HCLSIG). 

Eric has been a consultant for several pharmaceutical companies on how to improve their management of scientific and pharmacological information. Prior to FMI, Eric was a founder and CTO of PanGenX, a personalized medicine company. Eric was also the Global Head of Knowledge Management for Scientific and Medical Affairs within Sanofi-Aventis, overseeing the reuse of knowledge and insights across a multinational company. 

Eric is a graduate from MIT and holds a PhD in neurobiology, developmental genetics, and pharmacology from Case Western Reserve University.

"Making Mandalas in the Wild" with Patricia Gilmore, Artist/Therapist/International Speaker

Moss is not just moss and pine cones are not just pine cones. To an EcoArtist they are paints and textures to be skillfully combined in an organic piece of earth art. Join Patt Gilmore for a photographic tour and presentation of nature mandalas. From North to South America these images are sure to inspire you to get outside and have fun creating.
--------------------------------------------
Patricia is an environmental artist and therapist that works internationally. Her photographs have appeared in national art exhibitions. In 2014 she created the first Ames Mansion mandala in Easton. Her site specific land art is scattered throughout the USA and beyond. Recently she returned from making and photographing nature mandalas in Argentina. Several images of her earth art creations can be found in her ISSUU book “Nature Mandalas within an Urban Landscape.” http://issuu.com/pgilmore4/docs/nature_mandalas_within_an_urban_lan 

NOTE: Queset House is the beautiful stone house behind the Ames Library (an HH Richardson building). The 1920's gardens have been newly restored so come early to enjoy them before going inside.

results.description:
Winner of the 2009 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction


At times stern, at other times patient, at times perceptive, at other times in sad denial, Olive Kitteridge, a retired schoolteacher, deplores the changes in her little town of Crosby, Maine, and in the world at large, but she doesn’t always recognize the changes in those around her. As the townspeople grapple with their problems, mild and dire, Olive is brought to a deeper understanding of herself and her life–sometimes painfully, but always with ruthless honesty. Olive Kitteridge offers profound insights into the human condition--its conflicts, its tragedies and joys, and the endurance it requires. -via goodreads.com

PLEASE ARRIVE EARLY

Doors open at 6:30 PM

THE FILM WILL BEGIN PROMPTLY AT 7:00 PM!!!

Featured Film:  NAS: TIME IS ILLMATIC

Twenty years after the release of Nas’s groundbreaking debut album ‘Illmatic,’ NAS: TIME IS ILLMATIC takes us into the heart of his creative process. Returning to his childhood home in Queensbridge, Nas shares stories of his upbringing, his influences — from the music of his jazz musician father Olu Dara to the burgeoning hip-hop scene in New York City — and the obstacles he faced before his major label signing at age 20. Featuring interviews with his ‘Illmatic’ producers (Large Professor, Pete Rock, Q-Tip, L.E.S., and DJ Premier) and musical peers (including Pharrell Williams and Alicia Keys), NAS: TIME IS ILLMATIC is a thrilling account of Nas’s evolution from a young street poet to a visionary MC.

Run Time 74 minutes

Stay for the post film discussion

Hosted by Vernon aka VCR

Complimentery light refreshments will be available.

You're welcome to bring in your own food for yourself or to share.

For more information contact VCR at (617)[masked] or [masked]

While admission is FREE, your $5 donation is greatly appreciated.

results.description:
Thank you in advance to Rapid7 for hosting the location, providing food and beverages, and providing a lead presentation.

Security-related items:

RSVPs’ must include full names for the security desk and accessing the Rapid7 office. Any “+1” or “+2” additions to the event must ALSO supply their full name in advance. Please update your profile before June 9th so that you are not turned away at the door.

Address: 100 Summer Street, 13th Floor, Boston, MA 02110


Parking: 100 High Street, Boston, MA 02110   -OR-
125 Summer Street Boston, MA 02111



1st Presentation: AWS Infrastructure as code – automating away the cloud
Abstract: At Rapid7, we believe AWS infrastructure should be treated with the same standards as we treat the product code that makes up our software.  Wrapping CloudFormation with Ruby, we've crafted Convection - https://github.com/rapid7/convection; Using Convection, we can bring up an entire environment ready for hosting our applications.  From base VPC to Elasticache cluster to the last IAM policy, Convection is our tool of choice.
Presenter: Edward “EJ” Ciramella, Lead Engineer, Global Engineering Services (GES) DevOps/Cloud Ops team.

2nd Presentation: AWS CloudFormation and PowerShell DSC - Better Together
Abstract: Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) is a configuration management platform built into Windows Server 2012 R2 and available for installation on Windows Server 2008 R2 and Linux servers. DSC provides a consistent, declarative way to apply and maintain the configuration of servers regardless of the environment they're deployed in. In this presentation, after a quick intro to DSC, we'll explore how it can be used in conjunction with CloudFormation to bootstrap servers launched into an AWS environment. We'll also see how once your servers are up and running, DSC can be used to ensure they stay configured the way you want them.
Presenter: Joe Grenier is a Senior Software Engineer with BlueMetal Architects. In more than 15 years in IT he has worked across a variety of industries, including finance, health care, e-commerce and non-profit. Joe is a member of the Cloud and Services practice at BlueMetal where he focuses on hybrid-cloud architectures, disaster recovery and dev-ops, mainly on AWS and Azure. 

==========================================


Contact Mark Annati, the moderator, at [masked] with interest in future meetups; presenting or sponsoring (food, location). Thank you.

results.description:
Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:10pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:30pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.

results.description:
Directions:

To get to Wayfair in the Copley Offices, first go into Copley Mall and go to the center of it. At the very center of the mall, there are water works and lots of huge tropical-looking plants. Stores nearby include Dior, Hugo Boss, and Williams Sonoma. There will be elevators on one side of the mall, across from BCBG Max Azria, and then escalators on the other.

Take the elevators up to the “SKYLOBBY”. There will be someone at the security desk. They will need your ID. We will have provided a list of people to attend the event.

When you get past security, go to "4 Copley Place." Once inside those doors, get on an elevator and go up to the 7th floor. There will be a reception desk that will point you to the room that we will be in: "Palette"



ABOUT:

In this class, we'll take it slow and break it all down into digestible pieces so that you'll walk away with a strong understanding of the fundamentals. 

Though we are focusing on PHP, a widely used language that  powers sites like Facebook, Youtube, Wordpress, and Wikipedia, the concepts that you learn will be transportable to any programming language. 

Topics we'll cover:

• variables

• basic data structures

• loops

• if/else statements & case switch statements

• basic control flow

• functions

LEARNING STYLE

The class will be structured so that it will alternate between classroom style lecture and hands-on coding for the duration of the class. 

GOALS:

We want you to walk away with a strong understanding of how to code and be able to solve a basic programming puzzle, much like the ones that developers get asked in job interviews.

SCHEDULE:

We'll meet on Tuesdays and Thursdays for two weeks, starting on June 9th:

June 9th: 7:00 - 9:00pm

June 11th: 7:00 - 9:00pm

June 16th: 7:00 - 9:00pm

June 18th: 7:00 - 9:00pm


REQUIREMENTS:

No programming background needed. This class caters to newcomers, beginners, and those who want a stronger grasp of their fundamentals.

You do not have to be a woman to join our class--we are an inclusive organization and welcome any gender or identity.

****PLEASE NOTE: We'll use Macbooks in this class so everyone can be on the same page. Please reach out to us if you do not have a macbook.****

INSTRUCTOR:

Emily Xie is very passionate about teaching and helping others learn to code. She has previously taught advanced object oriented programming at BostonPHP, and she currently works at Wayfair as a software engineer. In her spare time, she enjoys cooking, photography, and playing Age of Empires II.

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct. 

****PLEASE NOTE: We'll use Macbooks in this class so everyone can be on the same page. Please reach out to us if you do not have a macbook.****
results.name: Intro to PHP - Focus on Fundamentals

results.description:
In the shift from the page from the screen, we've lost a little something along the way: the ability to easily transform any page with your own notes, scribbles, thoughts, and ideas. Let's meet up at the Harvard Innovation Lab (Room 150) to talk about digital engagement and new ways of restoring creativity to the process of interacting with content. 

Right now I'm working on a project called Papero (papero.co) that is trying to bring annotation into the 21st century. I'll give a little presentation at the beginning, then we can start riffing and talking about how media innovators are challenging our expectations of engaging with articles and texts online. We'll do a couple of workshop exercises to get us all thinking about digital engagement and what it could mean. 

This is my first Meetup and I'm excited about meeting all of you! 

xxx Ceci
results.how_to_find_us: Room 150 is on the right as you enter the big white+red Harvard Innovation Lab (iLab). Call Ceci on 857-285-8387 if you have any trouble finding it!
results.name: Let's talk about the future of digital annotation!

results.description: As one of the few times Nero Wolfe ever leaves his New York home, The Black Mountain is a significant departure from Stout's very successful formula - 33 novels and 40 novellas featuring Nero Wolfe.  With the nearly immobile and supremely rational Wolfe and the All-American Archie Goodwin as the recorder and narrator of his exploits, Stout created an interesting hybrid that incorporated the British puzzle mystery and the American action mystery. This one should provide some good material with which to understand these two important directions of the crime and mystery genre.  But it also contains an interesting historical snapshot of Cold War politics and attitudes.  And, if my memory serves me well, it should be an entertaining read.  See you in June.
results.name: June Meeting - Discussing The Black Mountain, by Rex Stout

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
{Come to this powerful event to reshape the way you think of habits and rituals.}

Neurological research seems to indicate that 90% or more of what we do is habitual. 


We will explore the current science of habit formation, and how to apply that to your life. New habit development is the single most leveraged action you can invest your willpower in.

The habits of Belief, Perception, Thinking, and Action are the keys to transforming who you experience yourself to be and what you accomplish in the world.

In this evening we will go beyond habit development to the high return on investment practice of rituals and routines. 

Where as a single habit is very beneficial, a new routine or ritual creates the patterns of life that create enjoyment, effectiveness, and success.

Through videos, discussion and exercises, Matthew will help us learn how to identify, create and establish new habits, routines, and rituals.

To Prepare ....

1.)  We will look at how to change ineffective habits.
What is one current result in your life, that you are not satisfied with. Can you identify the habit that keeps it that way?

2.) We will explore how to create new habits.
What is one practice, or way of being that you have “wanted” to begin or maintain, but have failed to develop the habit? What do you believe was in your way?

3.) We will identify the power of routine and ritual to shift us from “Doing” to “Being in Action”.
How much do you accomplish from force, discipline or willpower? Would you rather create it from enthusiasm, grace, and alignment?

Our Leader This Evening

Matthew Winston is a PGN Organizer and a long-time practitioner of Law of Attraction.   Matthew took his first personal growth seminars in 1992, and a decade later joined the Board of Insight New England.

Matthew has been a corporate trainer and consultant for over 20 years. For the last 7 years he has moved into personal coaching and small group workshops. His practice, OneSingleThing, focuses on three major areas: relationship coaching; entrepreneur coaching; and awakening coaching. He is also the owner of Kids OT To Play, a pediatric occupational therapy, speech therapy and behavioral therapy clinic.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
• Seating is limited to the first 15 registrations


Most real estate agents have 2 revenue streams: 

1. Working with buyers to purchase a home for them to live in and

2. Working with sellers by listing and their home. 

Learn how to add additional revenue streams to your real estate business by attending this lunch and learn event hosted by Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development. The presentation will focus on adding additional revenue streams to your real estate brokerage business including:


1. Making money by helping us acquire properties: Think it would be easier to approach an expired listing or FSBO with an offer in hand from a cash buyer?  We'll show you how to easily get in front of more sellers.
2. Our Automated Short Sale System:  Learn how to capitalize on short sales while keeping your sanity.  Our automated short sale program allows agents to spend a very limited amount of time and effort while maximizing their commissions.
3. Buyer Lead Overflow: we don't work with buyers, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't.  Learn how working with an investor can provide you with an overflow of buyer leads and how we generate these leads(mostly by accident).
4. Learn how to make money by wholesaling properties & raising capital: we'll show you how to easily and effectively add these two revenue streams to your real estate business.

As an added bonus, we will be reviewing our best practices and systems to allow you to leverage your time and efforts in 2015.  

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has acquired over 62 properties to fix and flip over the past 12 months. Environment & Structure of Event: The presentation will be held in our conference room in Wakefield and we will be providing lunch and refreshments. Seating is limited to the first 15 registrants and the presentation will be followed by a Question and Answer session. The presentation and Question and answer will end at approximately 12pm and for those who want to stick around or have additional 1 on 1 questions we will be ending at 12:30pm.
results.name: Making Money w/Ocean City - Lunch & Learn - Creating  Additional Revenue Streams

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
RSVP: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1MPydQ20xUSmHvVlVb1nvL94B9yPovtvHB67BSkpp15k/viewform

MIT Center for Advanced Urbanism, 1st Floor, Media Lab
http://cau.mit.edu/center/contact-directions

The United Nations estimates that there are 4 billion people who don't have an address. Not only is this one of the first steps to legal recognition and the associated social and economic development, it also means people can’t get basic services, such as post.

People need a simple, accurate and unambiguous address system. They could use GPS co-ordinates, but with 14-16 digits and some letters, they are too difficult to use for most people except professionals. Coordinates are also impossible to remember, even in the short term, and errors in understanding, transcription and communication make the widespread use of geospatial information prohibitive. what3words is a global address system based on a grid of 3mx3m squares. It uses an algorithmic engine similar to that of a coordinate system and has given each of the 57 trillion squares, a pre-assigned and fixed address of 3 words. It is currently available in 12 languages and integrated in a number of applications worldwide.

Come and listen to Steven Ramage talk about how what3words are addressing the world on June 10th at MIT... 

www.what3words.com

RSVP: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1MPydQ20xUSmHvVlVb1nvL94B9yPovtvHB67BSkpp15k/viewform

results.description:
Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street, Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T
Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.


Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop - <2 blocks away), behind the long wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm

A number of you have shown interest in a weekday evening meetup in the downtown Boston area. Here it is! Please come and join us for a casual 2 hours ASL social on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 7:30 pm.


WHO: All who are interested in ASL are welcome to join us. Whether you're Deaf or hearing, beginner or fluent ASL user, we're here to share and socialize in this beautiful language.

WHERE: We'll be in the Prudential Center Food Court on 800 Boylston Street in Copley Square. Since we'll most likely be the only group of people signing, we should be pretty easy to spot.

RULES: Voices off, use paper and pen if you need to--this helps us learn and its Deaf friendly


RESOURCES: For those of you who are new to ASL and want to come prepared, here are some very good websites with free online classes.

http://www.westwoodasl.com/ http://www.lifeprint.com/ http://www.start-american-sign-language.com/

results.description:
Come join me in exploring two major exhibitions of European art. Leonardo da Vinci and the Idea of Beauty and Restoring a Legacy  Rothschild Family Treasures!!

 Leonardo da Vinci and the Idea of Beauty


In an intimate exhibition featuring master drawings by Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, the star is a study of an angel that the art historian Sir Kenneth Clark called “the most beautiful…in the world.”

Leonardo da Vinci’s accomplishments in art and science find their common ground in his drawings, into which he poured the full fervor of his intelligence and creative powers. Throughout his career, Leonardo experimented with various types of drawings: scientific studies; grotesque caricatures of craggy faces; and the most beautiful faces of men and women that he could imagine. Many of Leonardo’s most admired drawings are featured in this rich and varied selection of 29 sheets and a manuscript, opening on April 15, fittingly Leonardo’s birthday.

One revelation for visitors will be the rarely displayed Codex on Flight, one of Leonardo’s most perceptive scientific explorations, with its nearly hidden self-portrait of Leonardo as a young man, a recent discovery. The exhibition features rare loans from a number of Italian public collections, including the Uffizi Museum in Florence, the Biblioteca Reale in Turin, and the Casa Buonarroti, the ancestral property of Michelangelo in Florence, which has lent eight drawings by that master.

Restoring a Legacy : Rothschild Family Treasures



This exhibition celebrates recent gifts to the MFA that tell a story of a great European collection, which was looted during the Nazi era and ultimately restored to its rightful owners. The collection of 186 objects, originally owned by Baron and Baroness Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild of Vienna, includes European decorative arts, furniture, prints, drawings, paintings, and personal objects including jewelry and jeweled objects, miniatures, and rare books, and is a gift of the heirs of Bettina Looram de Rothschild, who was a daughter of the Baron and Baroness. Her daughter, MFA Trustee Bettina Burr, is among the donors who have made this gift to the MFA.

results.name: MFA free Wednesday Art of Europe

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on the grassy patch between the Children's Museum & the Barking Crab Restaurant

results.description:
Would you like to enjoy the benefits of walking in nature but are not able to keep up with the pace or length of time of a typical group? This is the walk for you!
         • 1x/week for 13 weeks
         • Slow pace
         • 1 mile or less to start

Experience the therapeutic benefits of walking in nature. This 13 week program is designed for anyone who is interested in a short slow walk. Are you a beginner hiker, recovering from an injury/illness, or just prefer a short slow walk? We will begin at 5:50 pm with a short warm-up then set out on the trail promptly at 6:00 pm returning at 6:30 pm. 

Although we will only be out for a short time, being well supplied will contribute to your enjoyment. 

What to bring/wear:
         • Water
         • Hat/Sunglasses/Sunscreen
         • Comfortable shoes with ankle support
         • Clothing should be loose and easy for walking
         • Snack 
         • Walking stick or Trekking poles
         • Bug repellent

results.description:
My name is Bill Zinke, and at age 88 I am a person with a cause. The cause is to integrate the large and growing population segment of people 50+ more effectively into the economic and social fabric of America. I founded Enrich Life Over 50 to see this cause effectively achieved. 

Our goal is to create a National Network of Chapters cities for People 50+ in 27 major throughout the U.S. Boston will be the first one to launch because of its historic role in American history. It follows a successful pilot meeting we held in Raleigh, NC on March 14, which attracted 80 people 50+.  That event’s final session was titled “The Phenomenal Aspects of Growing Older” and featured two speakers: Dr. Janice Wassel, Assistant Professor of Gerontology at UNC Greensboro, and Judge William H. Webster, a well-known national leader who has served most of his life in public-service roles as a Federal Court of Appeals Judge, Director of the FBI and the CIA at different times and as Chairman of the Homeland Security Advisory Council since 2002. At age 91, he is still involved in numerous activities, including serving as a Director of ELO50. Bill Webster epitomizes the reality that many people in their 70s, 80s and 90s can continue adding value in America. 

The first meeting of the ELO50 Boston Chapter has the following two speakers already confirmed: Rev. Bill Harding, the Minister of the Church and Bill Zinke, Founder and President of ELO50. Each speaker will talk for 20 minutes, followed by 20 minutes of questions and group interaction. There will also be 60 minutes devoted to a moderated roundtable session devoted to any subjects participants would like to discuss, and one hour when the meeting ends devoted to socializing with refreshments. 

Some of the benefits of joining the ELO50 Boston Chapter are: acquiring new learning from the presentations and group interaction; gaining new perspectives on how to remain productively engaged and socially connected; resolving problems and developing new opportunities through discussion with similarly-situated people; participating in building a community of like-minded people with shared interests.

There will be 10 Chapter meetings per year, excluding July and August. The charge to join ELO50 is $500 annually, $750 for a member with significant other. The price for this meeting is $50, as it is the first and will be followed by a two-month hiatus. The balance of $450 for one person and $700 for a couple will be charged in September.

We hope many of you will join this action-oriented new group and support our cause. Please visit elo50.com for more information and to register for the ELO50 Boston meeting.

Regards,

Bill Zinke
results.how_to_find_us: For more information and to register visit: elo50.com
results.name: The Phenomenal Aspects of Growing Older

Otherwise just bring the ability to forgive the robber for stealing your sheep.

The ability to overlook how the other Munchkin players have stopped you from getting past level 9 ten times in a row and suddenly your down to level 8. Just breath, in and out, in and out.

Recent lesson learned: Never pull a ticket for NY to LA when another player only has 8 trains left. Keep those eyes open.

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

The format for the monthly meetings is that each person will introduce her- or himself and state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

--------------------


This meeting is located in the Starbucks inside what is called the "Boston Marriott" even though the hotel is located in Kendall Square, Cambridge. The Kendall Square subway stop is a Red Line stop at "Kendall."

This meeting is FREE and it repeats on the 2nd Wednesday of every month.
results.name: Boston Traders' Meetup Group Meeting 2nd Wednesday at 6 PM in Cambridge

results.description:
Welcome to the 5th Boston StockTwits Meetup for Investors and Traders! Big shout-out to everyone who has made it to multiple events. The group is getting really diverse and there's opportunity to learn about all asset classes, styles, and experiences.

In this next Meetup we'll be hosting two presentations and then a networking session afterward. This is the time to connect with likeminded traders and investors -- long-term, technical, swing trade, and quant. One of the big themes, so far, has been the growing number of people interested in options and futures. And so for that reason, these two topics will be the focus of our 5th meetup! 

Hope to see you there and please post any questions, comments, insights, and fun material on the comments section here.


If you missed the last Meetup, we heard from Alice Meade and Andrew Ghezzi. Alice showed us her automated trading software. Andrew gave us a preview of all the exciting things happening in fintech and how they've shaped his trading style and opinion about brokers.

results.description:
Like a fine bottle of wine, the Security of Things Meetup has sat quietly on the shelf. But now the time is right to pop the cork on this thing. 

We hope you can join us as we hold our inaugural MeetUp as a ride along with the Boston/New England IoT group on the evening of Wednesday, June 10 at the Cambridge Innovation Center.

Our special guest will be John Walsh, the Vice President of Sypris Solutions (Nasdaq/NM: SYPR) and President of Sypris Electronics, a D.C. based firm that is a leader in Electronics Manufacturing, Cryptography, High Assurance, Cryptographic Identity Management, Cyber Analytics/Operations and Training Services. 

John is a former leader in the Missile Defense Initiative and expert in lean engineering and Six-Sigma. Since joining Sypris, Mr. Walsh has transformed the company's mission to focus on its core competencies:  High Assurance and Secure/Severe/High Reliability to a value proposition based in “Trust”: Design & Manufacturing (Trusted Source); End Point Security; Networks & Infrastructure; and Cyber Operations and Analytics. Among the initiatives Sypris has undertaken under Mr. Walsh's leadership are "fourth factor” silicon-based Identity Management, Single Chip FPGA Crypto and an integrated Cyber Range and Training platform. 


This will be a a great evening of networking and learning. It is also a chance to meet and mingle with fellow IoT and security enthusiasts. We hope to see you there! 

If you have any questions or if you're a company interested in sponsoring this or other SECoT meet-ups, feel free to message me. 

-- Paul Roberts
results.name: Inaugural Security of Things Meetup - June 10!!

results.description:
Using the Mysterious Forces within a Company

You are smart, successful, ambitious, and getting caught in the things you hate most -- office politics and culture -- the “mysterious forces” that can confuse you and derail your career. But there is hope -- when you understand the most powerful human and organizational dynamics flowing around you, you can navigate more effectively. Debbie will present a model to help you observe and decode your enterprise atmosphere at micro and macro levels. The model can guide you to tune into subtle details and put them into a comprehensive, yet nuanced picture so you understand what is really going on. You will start putting your sociological detective work to use right in the workshop. Bring a brief description of one or two of your most challenging organizational conundrums so you can start untangling them and moving forward immediately.

This session will be in workshop form – part presentation, part small group work, part individual planning.

Deborah Ferro Burke MBA, PhD, created and delivered the Corporate Entry Leadership Program for early-career high-potentials at Crotonville, GE’s John F. Welch Global Leadership Center. She innovated broad-scale qualitative organization assessments throughout GE, and was a thought leader, manager, and later a consultant for Work-Out, the Change Acceleration Program, and Six-Sigma. She has consulted at the corporate and business levels in auto, chemical and insurance companies, growing tech companies, and at Simmons Graduate School of Business and Harvard University. She is a mentor/instructor at MIT’s Undergraduate Practice Opportunities Program (UPOP) and was associate professor at Rensselaer’s Lally School of Management and Technology. Debbie is currently coaching sales executives at a large technology company and fast track millennials facing quarter-life realignments. She has explored how people learn and organizations change in the recent publications below. She has an MBA and a PhD in Human and Organization Systems.

results.description:
Ever feel like your T-SQL solution to a tricky issue was almost just as difficult as the problem itself? Ever find yourself unable to cleanly express the logic you really need in T-SQL for your complex data calculation? Don't blame yourself--blame the limitations of the language. Get ready to embrace SQL Server's most powerful programming enhancement: turbocharged support for windowing functions. If you write analytical queries and you need results fast, attend this session to learn everything you need to know to leverage all the power that windowing functions bring to the table. You'll see examples taken from real-world projects that illustrate how to create running sums, calculate moving averages, look both backward and forward in your set, and achieve many other seemingly complex tasks -- all with ease and clarity. The hallmark of a truly great SQL Server feature is the ability to make difficult tasks simple. Windowing functions will have you writing better and faster T-SQL than ever before.

Adam Machanic is a Boston-based SQL Server developer, writer, and speaker. He focuses on large-scale data warehouse performance and development, and is author of the award-winning SQL Server monitoring stored procedure, sp_WhoIsActive. Adam has written for numerous web sites and magazines, including SQLblog, Simple Talk, Search SQL Server, SQL Server Professional, CoDe, and VSJ. He has also contributed to several books on SQL Server, including "T-SQL Querying" (Microsoft Press, 2015) and "SQL Server 2008 Internals" (Microsoft Press, 2009). Adam regularly speaks at conferences and training events on a variety of SQL Server topics. He is a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional (MVP) for SQL Server, a Microsoft Certified IT Professional (MCITP), and an alumnus of the INETA North American Speakers Bureau.
results.name: T-SQL Power! SQL Server Windows That Open Doors - Adam Machanic

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 6:30 by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking. Look for the beautiful, pasty white, blonde man with the green climbing shoes.


BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!


If you are looking for a partner or just want to get your climb on join us on Wednesdays for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to top rope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. The Wednesday meetup assures you'll meet a partner to regularly climb with. We are looking to expand to other nights in the future.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!):

Day Pass - $22 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 6:30 - 6:40 - they've been moving the benches all around so it's now the 3rd / not the 4th. But it's always the one in the middle of the TR / Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
Baron Schwartz of Vivid Cortex will give the following talk:

Title: Sampling Is Hard


So you're mining big fast streams of data... should be easy to get representative samples of it, right? That's what we thought, too. I'll talk about our goals for sampling and how counterintuitively hard it turned out to be, and what solutions we used to address it.

Baron is headlining this show.  Ben Clark will open for him, with a brief talk called "Scaling Performance Monitoring at Wayfair"

Ben is the Chief Architect of Wayfair and the organizer of this meetup.  Baron really needs no introduction, but just in case, here's his bio:

Baron Schwartz is the Founder and CEO of Vivid Cortex.  He is one of the world’s leading experts on MySQL, and has helped build and scale some of the largest web, social, gaming, and mobile properties. His award-winning tools are used by tens of thousands of large MySQL deployments, including Facebook and Twitter.
His book High Performance MySQL is widely acknowledged as the definitive reference for MySQL. As an author, consultant, speaker, and conference organizer, Baron has deep connections in the MySQL and DevOps communities and beyond, extending to a variety of databases, cloud and big data, and open source.

Before founding VividCortex, Baron led sales, marketing, consulting, support, and software engineering at Percona, the leading MySQL consulting and support company.

Pizza is at 6:30.  The talks will start at 7:15.
results.how_to_find_us: Kendall/MIT T station, short walk. This is the same building Akamai has been in, re-addressed by the city from '8 Cambridge Center'
results.name: Baron Schwartz: Sampling is hard

We're talking about how to achieve alignment in large organizations. DevOps is an organizational shift, not just a technical one. How can we encourage different departments and teams to move in the same direction? Competing incentives can make this difficult.

First off, we'll have a couple speakers from XebiaLabs give a brief talk on what they've done to improve alignment.

Then we'll have a workshop that will highlight misconceptions that can cause departments and teams to diverge from overall goals.

Not into a workshop? That's okay! We'll have breakout sessions focused on DevOps in larger organizations. This is the space to talk about topics like blameless postmortems, cross-functional meetings, service/provider relationships and so on.

results.description:
Be part of the first Liberating Structures practice and collaboration group in the greater Boston area. Come and bring one or more colleagues, friends or collaborators! You will learn, share experiences and connect with other users. No experience necessary! LS will help you transform how groups of any size collaborate to solve problems, plan, strategize, innovate... Everybody benefits from using LS. 


Liberating Structures is about action, engagement and collaborative change – practiced through 33 (and growing) easy-to-use, powerful, and continually adaptive group engagement “structures” designed to surface insights, ideate, identify best practices, strategize, or help people see what they can do to make change happen. This group will be focused on exploring Liberating Structures through practice (doing them at the Meetups) as well as sharing experience / knowledge about applying them in work contexts and by exploring opportunities for collaboration and projects. 

During our launch meet-up, you will discover the diversity of applications and experiences of practicing Liberating Structures. We are especially excited to have Keith McCandless, Henri Lipmanowicz, authors of the LS book http://www.amazon.com/The-Surprising-Power-Liberating-Structures/dp/0615975305 with us for this event.

Find out for yourself how quickly you can start to integrate Liberating Structure into your work and organizations. They are well laid out, designed to be accessible, and ready to start using. You can explore the step-by-steps for all 33 structures, available to anyone on the Liberating Structures website: (http://www.liberatingstructures.com/ls/)

This group is open to anyone; no experience necessary, just a willingness to learn and share.

Special thanks to Suffolk University Center for Innovation and Change Leadership for providing the meeting space.

results.name: Explore and integrate Liberating Structures into your work  & organizations

results.description:
Though indisputably patriotic, Revere, like so many others, possessed a personality far more complex than a single defining moment would suggest. Mr. Greenburg will speak about the historical record of Paul Revere, from the Midnight Ride through his lesser-known travails and ultimate trial by court-marital following the doomed Penobscot Expedition – a troubling and often ignored chapter in the life of this beloved American icon.

This lecture is presented in collaboration with Old South Meeting House and the Paul Revere House and is sponsored by Lowell Institute.

Book signing to follow.


This lecture is FREE and open to the public. No registration is required.
results.name: The Court-Martial of Paul Revere (Book Talk)

results.description:
Skip Shea is an award winning filmmaker, writer, artist and actor from Uxbridge, Massachusetts.

His short horror film Ave Maria won the Audience Award at the Interiora Horror Festival in Rome,Italy, Most Weird and Wonderful Film at the Mascara and Popcorn Festival in Montreal, Canada,Runner Up Fan Favorite Award at the 2014 Tally Shorts Festival in Tallahassee, Florida and Jury Award for Honorable Mention For Best Horror Film at the SENE Film, Art and Music Festival in Providence,RI. It also screened as part of the Hollyshorts Horror Nights with Justin Beahm at the TCL Chinese Theater in Hollywood.

His short horror film Microcinema won Best Short at the 2012 Jersey Gore Film Festival as well as a 2011 Rondo Hatton Honorable Mention for Best Horror Short.

His short comedy Choices won the Best New England Film at the 2012 Massachusetts Independen tFilm Festival. Children of the Asylum won the Audience Award for Best Regional Short at the 2013 SENE Film Festival. Out of the Night won Best Horror/Thriller Short at the 2013 Worcester Film Festival. The Actor took Honorable Mention as Best Regional Short at the 2014 SENE Film Festival.

He has a feature length screenplay adaptation of his horror short Microcinema which was a finalist at the Woods Hole Film Festival and semi-finalist at the 2112 Shriekfest. His script The Bar took the Runner-Up Award in the Comedy Short Screenplay competition at the 19th Annual Woods Hole Film Festival.

He was the head writer on the Emmy Award Nominated Web Series Beacon Hill.

He also wrote, produced and performed a one man show “Catholic (Surviving Abuse & Other Dead End Roads)” which chronicles his life as a survivor of clergy sexual abuse and debuted in 2005 in New York City.
results.name: Lifespan of the Short Film with Skip Shea

results.description:
Want to relax, doing Tai Chi and becoming a Chinese Tea tasting expert?  Try our Combination of Tai Chi and Tea Ceremony/Incense Demonstration!

Tai Chi-7-8pm

Following Sifu Huan, and doing the first 13 movements of Yang Style Tai Chi. Huan is the 6th generation of Yang Style Tai Chi. He is also the author of the book "Seeing Beyond the Tai Chi Footprint". You have seen his articles featured in the international Tai Chi Magazine. He studied under 3 Grandmasters from Yang family. David Watts will start the warm up and then give instructions of detailed Tai Chi movements.


Incense Demonstration 8:00- 8:20pm


Sifu Huan will close the class with a Chinese Incense demonstration. He will create a Chinese character with incense powders using unique tools . The audience will be able to enjoy the fragrances of  incense and see the process within a beautiful ceramic cup.  

Tea Tasting- 8:20pm-9pm


Huan will then do a tea tea-tasting ceremony. He will present few top quality tea from China and is looking forward to sharing both the tea itself and the knowledge about the tea. Tea is limited, so this is a rare opportunity. We hope you will be able to join this special occasion to learn more about Tai Chi and Chinese tea!

* We will do tea tasting (not tea drinking), so you will not drink a lot of tea to keep you awake. You will have little tea to relax you and help you rest later.

Huan's Tai Chi, 7 Temple Street, Cambridge (direct entrance into our studio is inside the YWCA building near Central Square T Station)

Fee: $10 for Tai Chi class, $10 for Incense Demonstration, Tea Ceremony is FREE come with the Incense Demonstration or Tai Chi class,  $15 for class+Incense.

All ages welcome!
results.how_to_find_us: @ YWCA building, 1st door on right, no the double door
results.name: Relaxing night with Tai Chi & Tea Ceremony/Incense Demonstration

This class sets its own agenda dealing with current events, current planetary placement such as lunar cycles or retrograde planets. Discussions are centered on these factors and how they impact us on a more personal level as individuals.

Come on by and join the fun!

Namaste'

results.description:
William Damon discusses The Power of Ideals: The Real Story of Moral Choice

Monday, June 10, 2015, 7pm

Harvard Book Store

1256 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

This event is free and includes a book signing; no tickets are required.

Harvard Book Store welcomes Stanford professor and author of eighteen previous books WILLIAM DAMON for a discussion of his latest book, The Power of Ideals: The Real Story of Moral Choice, co-authored by Anne Colby. 

Cynicism often seems a smarter choice than idealism. There are reasons for this. Politicians have disappointed us time and again; trusted institutions have proven to be self-serving and corrupt; hopes for lasting world peace repeatedly have been dashed; and social inequities persist and increase, unabated by even the grandest of charitable efforts. It is now considered foolish to think that people can be counted on to rise above their narrow self-interests to serve the broader good, or to tell the truth if it does not reflect well on the self. Supporting this bleak view of the human condition is a moral psychology that has taken increasingly cynical turns in recent years. Famous studies have shown that we have an almost unlimited potential for cruelty when placed in the wrong situations.

The Power of Ideals presents a different vision, supported by a different kind of evidence. It examines the lives and work of six 20th century moral leaders who pursued moral causes ranging from world peace to social justice and human rights. Using these six cases to illustrate how people can make choices guided by their moral convictions, rather than by base emotion or social pressures, authors William Damon and Anne Colby explore the workings of three virtues: inner truthfulness, humility, and faith. Through their portrayal of the noble lives of moral leaders, the authors argue that all of us--with ordinary lives--can exercise control over important life decisions and pursue ideals that we believe in.

Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked] 

Accessibility Inquiries: [masked]
results.name: Moral Choice

results.description:
When extracting herbs into alcohol or infusing them in water, we can only pull a fraction of the plant’s constituents in either solvent. For many plants this suits our purposes fine, but some have both water- and alcohol-soluble constituents, and we’d like to keep both in our finished medicines.

Powdering is one of the best ways to preserve all the medicinal qualities of our plants, while also getting them into an easily-absorbed form. Taking a teaspoonful of dry powder, though, isn’t a very appealing prospect!

Come learn to make and use your own herbal powders – and how to blend them with nut butters, honey, and ghee to make tasty and healing edibles. Go beyond your standard Zoom Balls to nourishing, soothing, and vitalizing remedies. Put the power of powders to work for you!

No prior experience necessary. This class will be hands-on, simple and fun! We’ll have plenty of tastings and stories to share.

Wednesday, June 10th, 2015
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $25.
Register for class by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Making Herbal Medicines; The Power of Powders

results.description:
Have you ever wondered what it would take to create a Chrome Extension?
Well, it's easier than you might think. If you know basic Javascript, HTML, & CSS, then you can create your first Chrome Extension.

Andrei McMillan of Yieldbot will dive into this topic and cover:

- types of extensions
- extension api
- coding / unit test
- publishing your extension
- dev cycle of Yieldbot’s Chrome Extension
- Q & A

Github Project: https://github.com/amcmillan01/chrome_extension
Continuous Integration: https://travis-ci.org/amcmillan01/chrome_extension
Chrome Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/extension1/lcldgjakanbfmdgleoekbbelmaikolck?hl=en-US&gl=US

*Developers of all levels are welcome.*

Pizza and soda will be provided.

Location: Yieldbot offices Maynard, 1 Clock Tower Place, Suite 330
Park in the parking lot off of Main St. or in the parking garage.
Enter the building by the parking garage and up to the 3rd floor.

This event is designed to engage white allies, and folks of all races are invited to participate.
