results.description:
This is part two of the Introduction to Night Photography series, where we will be focusing (!) on photographing the night sky, particularly stars. This is an intermediate to advanced lecture, prerequisite for this lecture is that you either attended part I, the Introduction to Night Photography or you have at least experience shooting at night. Even though I will briefly go over basic settings again, we will not spend much time on that.

This event is for paid members only and it is a member benefit free of cost. If you haven't done so yet, please make sure to pay your membership online, there is a link to the left to do so. This lecture alone will make your annual fee worth it.

There is also a night shoot scheduled soon after this lecture, so that we can practice what we learned. Attendance will be preferred to participants of this lecture, but others can come, too. You will need to sign up separately for the shoot. In addition, there will be a substantial number of events throughout this summer specifically for astro-landscape shooting in places like western MA and Acadia NP.


There are three parts to the workshop:

(a) this lecture of about 90 minutes

(b) a night shoot soon after the lecture and

(c) online critique for the pictures you took to get detailed feedback on your assignment execution here on this site (if you post your photos).

The lecture will cover these topics:

Definitions
Equipment
Techniques
    Exposure settings
    White balance
    Darkness and Light pollution, where to shoot, light painting
    Focusing on stars, live demo
Types of astro-landscape photography
    Star trails: nature and urban
    Star points & Milky Way
    Clouds
    Moon
    Meteors
    Aurora
Image Processing
    Star trails: stacking photos
    Milky Way / Star points and Aurora
Resources
results.name: Lecture: Astro-landscapes - Photographing stars, trails, Milky Way and Aurora

JP Comics & Games in Jamaica Plain is now running a table for players interested in the newly-begun season of D&D 5e weekly Encounters every Wednesday from 7-9.

"Unearth the Deception" and help stop the forces of Elemental Evil from plunging the Sword Coast into chaos. Designed to take players from level 1 to level 5 by the time the season ends in August, this is a great way to (re)introduce yourself to D&D's current edition and get immersed in a storyline that harks back to the origins of the game.

Pre-generated characters are available, as is help to build your own, so feel free to drop in or contact Ted Atkinson if you'd like more information.

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of ten attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

RSVP-ING HERE DOES NOT GUARANTEE ADMISSION, PRE-REGISTRATION  THROUGH MY WEBSITE INSIGHTFULTRANSFORMATION.COM IS REQUIRED, CLICK HERE and then choose Free Group Healing 6/10/15 from the list of services

results.description:
There are many ways to get here:

Green Line:  The BU Central and BU West T stops are a short walk away.  Just cross the BU bridge, go under the overpass and onto Brookline st (it is straight ahead).  After a few blocks turn right on Allston (it's 1 block past the pizza place).  I'm the 2nd house on the right. 

Red Line:  The Central Square T stop is a short walk as well.  When you get out, walk down Mass Ave (toward MIT, not Harvard) and turn right on Brookline St (it's the corner with the Middle East Restaurant on it).  After about a 10 minute walk, turn left on Allston St.  I'm the 2nd house on the right.  

Bus:  The 47 Bus stops right around the corner on Brookline St (going toward mass ave) and Pearl (coming from mass ave) St. It's about a 1 block walk to the apt either way.   From Pearl and Allston, just walk down toward Allston St and past Brookline St.  From Putnam and Brookline St, walk toward Allston and turn right.

Driving:  I don't recommend driving; parking in Cambridge can be ... challenging.  If you do drive, there is metered parking on Erie St between Sydney and Waverley and on Emily St between Brookline and Sydney.  There's also a pay garage on Erie between Sydney and Waverley.  Or you could try Allston st itself at your risk.  I don't think they bother giving tickets after-hours -- but don't hold me to that.

Powdering is one of the best ways to preserve all the medicinal qualities of our plants, while also getting them into an easily-absorbed form. Taking a teaspoonful of dry powder, though, isn’t a very appealing prospect!

Come learn to make and use your own herbal powders – and how to blend them with nut butters, honey, and ghee to make tasty and healing edibles. Go beyond your standard Zoom Balls to nourishing, soothing, and vitalizing remedies. Put the power of powders to work for you!

No prior experience necessary. This class will be hands-on, simple and fun! We’ll have plenty of tastings and stories to share.

Wednesday, June 10th, 2015
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $25.
Register for class by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Making Herbal Medicines; The Power of Powders

results.description:
The Boston Austrian Economics Groupwill meet to discuss the Depression of 1920-21.

READING:

"Warren Harding, curing a depression through austerity"
http://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/warren-harding-curing-a-depression-through-austerity/2012/01/19/gIQA5VEsEQ_story.html

VIDEO/AUDIO:

"1921: The Crash That Cured Itself"
http://www.cato.org/events/forgotten-depression-1921-crash-cured-itself

STUDY QUESTIONS:

1. How long did it take for employment levels to return to “normal” in the Depression of 1920? The Great Depression? The Great Recession?

2. What monetary and fiscal policy did Harding and his Fed chief pursue? How does this contrast with responses to the Great Depression and Great Recession? What does the Keynesian School advocate in response to downturns? The Chicago School? The Austrian School?

3. What was happening to consumer prices when Harding took office? Why might this have been happening?

4. What happened to consumer prices when Harding was in office? Why might this have happened? Did the change in prices take place primarily in asset/capital or consumer prices? 

5. If the Fed had pursued Milton Friedman’s policy of keeping the money supply and price level stable, what would it have needed to do? Could the Fed have pursued Keynes’ suggestions without taking the drastic step that is the answer to number one?

6. What did the Fed chief call for in his speeches during the time?

7. Was there a deflationary spiral that led to a total banking collapse during[masked]?

8. A high savings rate led to a massive gold inflow and eventually boosted asset prices back up to pre-recession levels. Where did that capital go? What is the Austrian terminology for this? Is it the same as the mainstream terminology?

9. When savings rates skyrocketed in 1920, the monetary base expanded as gold came in from around the world to take advantage of the high savings rate. How is this different from the expansion of the monetary base that took place in 2007?

10. If the Fed just kept the monetary base constant and stopped engaging in QE, would this stop the boom/bust cycle? Would it be an improvement?
results.how_to_find_us: We are at the long table in the back left.
results.name: Depression without Stimulus: 1920-21

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
We'll discuss Celeste Ng's bestselling Everything I Never Told You at our June book club. Here's what it says about it on Amazon:

“Lydia is dead. But they don’t know this yet.” So begins this exquisite novel about a Chinese American family living in 1970s small-town Ohio. Lydia is the favorite child of Marilyn and James Lee, and her parents are determined that she will fulfill the dreams they were unable to pursue. But when Lydia’s body is found in the local lake, the delicate balancing act that has been keeping the Lee family together is destroyed, tumbling them into chaos. A profoundly moving story of family, secrets, and longing,Everything I Never Told You is both a gripping page-turner and a sensitive family portrait, uncovering the ways in which mothers and daughters, fathers and sons, and husbands and wives struggle, all their lives, to understand one another.


Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Do you ever experience this scenario: It's your turn to share what you do. You have 1, 2 or sometimes 10 minutes to talk about yourself and your business, so that the attendees of the meeting will want to refer business to you.

You have no idea what to mention, how to start, or even how to organize all your thoughts. That is, if you can even think of something important to say about yourself without boring the audience or feeling like you bragging or selling.

You want to engage the audience, so that they will not only listen to what you are sharing, but respond by talking with you afterwards and sending referrals your way, or becoming your client. You want the audience to leave feeling more confident about your abilities around the service you provide.

During this workshop, you will:


• Learn the #1 thing you must mention during this time

• Discover how to grab the attention of the audience

• Get the right people to talk to you after your little speech

• Find out what to add to be memorable and noticed

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP ORGANIZER

Kim Reddington is a speaker, trainer and business coach and the founder of Cereus Women. She works with success-driven women entrepreneurs and exceptional “Cereus” men to help them use speaking to build their practice and get all the clients they want. She has been an entrepreneur since 1995, which has enabled her to stay home with her 3 children while doing things that she loves.  Kim now gets most of her clients through speaking and referrals, and she wants to share her secrets with you.
results.name: Gaining Positive Attention During a Short Networking Pitch

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Join us at the EMC Cambridge Innovation Center on Thursday, June 11th from 6:00 to 8:00 pm.  We have a great speaker: Chip Childers, Technology Chief of Staff, Cloud Foundry Foundation. 


Title:  The Makings of a Modern Application Architecture

It wasn’t too long ago that artisans, bathed in the glow of molten metal, forged parts that would go on to make up bigger, more powerful machines. Today, we call those artisans developers. Instead of metal, they use bits and bytes in the cloud to forge a modern application architecture that supports public, private and hybrid application deployment. One that enables users and developers to move their applications wherever they need to go. And it’s built on a growing, vibrant ecosystem.

Nowhere is this epic shift in how things are made more visible than the meteoric adoption of Cloud Foundry. In this talk, Cloud Foundry technology chief of staff Chip Childers will give attendees an inside look at the economic forces that have made Cloud Foundry the fastest growing open source project in history.

He will also provide a look at the technologies driving this new level of efficiency for application developers (tech like containers, Docker, Kubernetes, OpenStack, Cloud Foundry and social coding tools like GitHub). And he’ll explain why many prominent members of the Fortune 500 are building their futures on this modern application architecture.

Speaker: Chip Childers, Technology Chief of Staff, Cloud Foundry Foundation
results.how_to_find_us: 2nd floor
results.name: The Makings of a Modern Application Architecture

group.name: The Boston Area Cloud Foundry Meetup

results.description:
Museum of African American History will commemorate the 90th birthday (May 19th) of slain civil rights leader, Malcolm X as well as the 50th anniversary of his assassination with his daughter Ilyasah Shabazz.

Ilyasah Shabazz is an author of critically acclaimed books celebrating the life of her father, Shabazz shares personal reflections from her early years with him through excerpts from her books, speaks about events that inspired his life's work, and tells how his voice, beliefs, and lessons were a vital part of her childhood and a powerful influence on who she has become.

Ilyasah Shabazz (pronounced Ill-yah-sah Shah-bozz) is an author, producer, and motivational speaker who lectures to capacity audiences across the country. ForGrowing Up X, a compelling and lyrical coming of age story, she earned an NAACP Image Award nomination, BET best book list pick, United Press International book of the week.

In 2014, Shabazz released her first children’s book Malcolm Little, The Boy Who Would Grow Up To Become Malcolm X(Simon and Schuster) beautifully illustrated has met with overwhelming response.

And now the long awaited The Diary of Malcolm X (Third World Press), co-authored  by Herb Boyd and Shabazz, documents Malcolm X's Pilgramage to MECCA and his stay in Africa and the Middle East. It captures the ever evolving leader and thinker, his reflections, and his immense passions, and in many ways amplifies his autobiography.

Just released January, 2015, X: A Novel (Candlewick Press) -- co-written with the award-winning young adult author Kekla Magoon, who also co-authored Malcolm Little -- is a riveting and revealing book that follows the formative years of the man whose words and actions shook the world. Timed with the 50th  Anniversary of his death (February 21), ”X” follows Malcolm from his childhood to his imprisonment for theft at age 20, when he found the faith that would lead him to forge a new path and command a voice that still resonates today.

Shabazz, who retraced her father’s footsteps to the Holy City of Mecca, is included in the 500 Most Influential Muslims in the World.

ADMISSION:

MAAH Members: FREE

Adults: $5

Youth (13 - 17) and seniors (62+): $3;

Space is limited | Accessible


You MUST RSVP via

email  [masked]

call to (617)[masked]<a></a> x222

Public Transportation

Take the Red or Green Line to Park Street.

Walk up Park toward the State House (gold dome) to Beacon Street.

Turn left onto Beacon and right onto Joy Street.

The Museum is located at 46 Joy Street.

Take the Blue Line to Bowdoin Street (Monday-Friday only 6:30 am to 6:30 pm)

Cross Cambridge Street

Turn right and walk one block and turn left on Joy Street

Directions by Car

FROM STORROW DRIVE

Take Government Center exit  and continue straight ahead onto Cambridge Street [pass Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) on left] approx. 1/2 mile to Joy Street (on right). Park and walk to Joy Street. Use map or call for drop off directions.

Nearby Parking

There are several parking lots and garages nearby;

closest is: Charles River Garage

209 Cambridge Street (near MGH). Normal rates apply; except with validated ticket and parked in approved lot

Walk out of garage and turn left onto Cambridge Street, go one block to Joy Street, turn right and walk up hill.

Validated Parking

DISCOUNTED PRICE: $5.00

Only in APPROVED LOT: Charles River Garage

Under the Whole Foods and the Wyndham Hotel

Only park on lower level

• weeknights after 4pm

• weekends after 10am

Bring your ticket to the Museum Store for validation stamp

results.description:
The health tech industry has really taken off over the past couple of years. From wearable fitness devices, to apps that help you track your daily calorie intakes, to even exercise routine apps, there is something out there for everyone. 

Tech in Motion Boston is excited to host this interactive and informative demo event at District Hall in the Seaport with local startups who are helping people live healthier and more fit lives. If you are someone who is just getting started, a fitness guru, or even a tech junkie, make sure to check out this event! 

Demo Companies:

MeYou Health offers a well-being program that helps people eat better, walk more, quit smoking, and make small but meaningful changes.

Lose It! is the industry-leading digital health and fitness platform that is centered on the proven principles of calorie tracking and community support for healthy, sustainable weight loss. 

WOO Sports is an innovative wearable for action sports that measures things like airtime, jump height, g-force, slope conditions, among many other key metrics.


Revvo is a smart exercise bike. Unlike apps and wearables that track activity (steps, calories etc.), Revvo actually tracks your fitness level - and guides you to train smart - so you spend less time training yet see a quicker increase in your fitness.

Virgin Pulse is a technology company with a mission to replenish the modern worker. Their SaaS platform is engaging, effective, and beautifully designed, their suite of health and well-being products build daily habits in a wide range of areas, driving incredible results for enterprise customers.

Affectiva brings emotional intelligence to the digital world. Using optical sensors, Affectiva technology and science map people’s facial expressions into emotions, unobtrusively and at scale.  

VirZOOM is a combination of patented sensors and software as well as exciting Virtual Reality experiences.  VirZOOM sensors turn your own bicycle or stationary bike into the ideal VR controller! 

Applause launched in 2008 as uTest, they are a leading application quality company. Applause enables companies to deliver digital experiences that win - from web to mobile to wearables and beyond. 


Learn More About Our Headline Sponsor:


CVS Health

CVS Health, through our unmatched breadth of service offerings, is transforming the delivery of health care services in the U.S. We are an innovative, fast-growing company guided by values that focus on teamwork, integrity and respect for our colleagues and customers. What are we looking for in our colleagues? We seek fresh ideas, new perspectives, a diversity of experiences, and a dedication to service that will help us better meet the needs of the many people and businesses that rely on us each day. As the nation’s largest pharmacy health care provider, we offer a wide range of exciting and fulfilling career opportunities across our three business units – MinuteClinic, pharmacy benefit management (PBM) and retail pharmacy. Our energetic and service-oriented colleagues work hard every day to make a positive difference in the lives of our customers.


Learn More About Our Social Sponsor:

One Medical

One Medical Group is an innovative, patient-centered primary care practice that brings your health care to the 21st century. They offer same and next day high-quality appointments with primary care providers who care, appointment booking over our website or mobile app, and accept most major health insurance plans. To help you maintain optimal health and wellness, One Medical is offering you 3 free months of membership at their convenient Government Center location (normally $199/year). Simply use code TIM2015 during online registration at onemedical.com. (Valid for new Boston members only – expires 8/11/15.)


Learn More About Our Strategic Partner: 

MIT Technology Review

MIT Technology Review, which is wholly owned by MIT, creates award-winning technology-related editorial content on a variety of platforms for an audience of millions of business leaders, innovators, and thought leaders, in six languages and in 147 countries. At www.technologyreview.com, readers access daily news and analysis, and the award-winning MIT Technology Review magazine has set the standard for technology publications since 1899. In addition to producing engaging live events, the company manages the global entrepreneurial organization MIT Enterprise Forum.

As always a huge thank you to our monthly sponsors Jobspring Partners and Workbridge Associates. 

For live updates on the meetup follow us on Twitter @Tech_in_Motion, @JobspringBoston and @WorkbridgeMA. We look forward to meeting you at this fun-filled,  networking event. Feel free to bring a friend along! 

Interested in sponsoring Tech in Motion? Reach out to Courtney or Cara!
results.name: Health & Wellness Demos and Drinks (Sponsored by CVS Health)

results.description:
Don't you want to help local kids? 

Don't you want to easily meet new people? 

On June 11th, the students of Ivy Street School and Boston Volunteers will take center stage as they perform in the school’s fourth annual Extravaganza! The event is the talent show spectacular in which Ivy Street School's students sing, dance, act, and thrill the crowd as they prove what we already know: they are stars!

On the outside, you would not even realize most of the students have a disability, looking at them. They look like a group of “normal” teenagers. But internally they face a range of challenges. Some students have suffered traumatic brain injuries as results of sports injuries or accidents. Some have acquired brain injuries, resulting from illness or brain tumors. Others are faced with challenges of autism spectrum disorder. No two brain injuries look alike and no two diagnoses look alike, so each student has a unique set of challenges. Some have memory loss. Memorizing song lyrics for a performance is no easy feat. Others are mobility impaired. Dance routines are a real challenge. Yet all students have one thing in common: they dream of performing in front of a packed house.

The event will be held at 6 p.m. the Berklee Performance Center located at 136 Massachusetts Avenue in Boston. Admission is FREE. We are hoping to help the Ivy Street School double the size of the audience by bringing 150 - 200 Boston Volunteers to help pack the house, cheer, sing, and give these students the audience that they deserve! 

A couple popular Meetups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Do you like adventuring: Boston Adventurers

Are You a FooDie: Discover Favorite Restaurants

This year’s special guest performers include local band Flipside, professional Elton John impersonator Bill Connors, Boston Improv actor Mac Gostow, and magician David Hall. Students perform in each and every act, whether it be singing with the musicians, acting in a skit, or serving as a magician’s assistant. The event will be hosted by former WCVB broadcaster David Brown, whose energy and enthusiasm always help make the night a success! 

The Ivy Street School is a residential school in Brookline, MA, for adolescents aged 13-22 with autism spectrum disorder, brain injuries, and other neurological challenges. The school is one of only a handful in the country that specializes in behavioral health diagnoses, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), post high school transition programming, and brain injury and other neurological transitioning. http://www.ivystreetschool.org 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and Andrea

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

results.description: Come dragon boat with Living Root! We're a co-ed team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive.  We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us.  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked]. Check out our website or find us on Facebook!

results.description:
Break out your neon, your leg warmers, and your MC Hammer pants--for this one night only Boston Grown-Ups Museum is kickin it old school! Go for gold in our jump rope contest, grab an adult snow cone, and hang out in our outdoor lounge while the DJ spins some throwback hits.
Get ready to crawl to the top of our three-story Climb, blow a giant bubble, play in our Construction Zone, and rediscover your most playful self? Now is your chance! It's time to party at Boston Children's Museum...without the children!

On Thursday, June 11th, we're throwing open the doors to Boston Children's Museum to those who are young at heart. Enjoy beer and wine plus tasty treats for purchase. Bring friends and meet new ones as you explore interactive exhibits, attempt to build a "big kid" sized fort, and explore your inner artist in the Art Studio. Stop into our Museum Shop and buy old favorites such as Pop Rocks, Pez dispensers and Gummy Worms.

Whether you were here as a kid or are new to town, Boston "Grown-Ups" Museum will bring out your innate sense of fun!

Let me know if your interested and get your tix here! http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-grown-ups-museum-tickets-16842346913

***This is not an official group meetup, but rather an event organized by another group that might be of interest to our members*** Tech in Motion is organizing a Health & Wellness Demos & Drinks Event. Some wearable tech will be present. From the event description: "The health tech industry has really taken off over the past couple of years. From wearable fitness devices, to apps that help you track your daily calorie intakes, to even exercise routine apps, there is something out there for everyone. Tech in Motion Boston is excited to host this interactive and informative demo event at District Hall in the Seaport with local startups who are helping people live healthier and more fit lives. If you are someone who is just getting started, a fitness guru, or even a tech junkie, make sure to check out this event! Demo Companies: MeYou Health offers a well-being program that helps people eat better, walk more, quit smoking, and make small but meaningful changes.

Lose It! is the industry-leading digital health and fitness platform that is centered on the proven principles of calorie tracking and community support for healthy, sustainable weight loss. WOO Sports is an innovative wearable for action sports that measures things like airtime, jump height, g-force, slope conditions, among many other key metrics."

Doesn't look like there is a ticket required, but arrive early to be guaranteed entry - this will be a popular event!

results.description:
Don't you want to help local kids? 

Don't you want to easily meet new people? 

On June 11th, the students of Ivy Street School and Boston Volunteers will take center stage as they perform in the school’s fourth annual Extravaganza! The event is the talent show spectacular in which Ivy Street School's students sing, dance, act, and thrill the crowd as they prove what we already know: they are stars!

On the outside, you would not even realize most of the students have a disability, looking at them. They look like a group of “normal” teenagers. But internally they face a range of challenges. Some students have suffered traumatic brain injuries as results of sports injuries or accidents. Some have acquired brain injuries, resulting from illness or brain tumors. Others are faced with challenges of autism spectrum disorder. No two brain injuries look alike and no two diagnoses look alike, so each student has a unique set of challenges. Some have memory loss. Memorizing song lyrics for a performance is no easy feat. Others are mobility impaired. Dance routines are a real challenge. Yet all students have one thing in common: they dream of performing in front of a packed house.

The event will be held at 6 p.m. the Berklee Performance Center located at 136 Massachusetts Avenue in Boston. Admission is FREE. We are hoping to help the Ivy Street School double the size of the audience by bringing 150 - 200 Boston Volunteers to help pack the house, cheer, sing, and give these students the audience that they deserve! 

A couple popular Meetups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Do you like adventuring: Boston Adventurers

results.description:
A Tail of 2.0 Curves 
by Philip Poots

When it comes to frameworks, the learning curve and the adoption curve are often inextricably intertwined. Let’s look at how Ember 2.0 is simplifying conceptually and how that affects the speed with which you can pick it up. We’ll also consider the areas we can improve on when welcoming newcomers.

ember-cli-deploy
by Raymond Cox

Does your Ember Deploy depend on your Backend Deploy? Does it make you want to throw you keyboard across the room? Learn how to separate the two for a faster, more flexible deploy.

Lightning Talks

We have a few spots open for lightning talks. If you'd like to give one, let us know on Twitter (@BostonEmber) or our Slack channel.
results.name: A Tail of 2.0 Curves by Philip Poots and ember-cli-deploy by Raymond Cox

results.description:
Boston Clojure Group Meetups are held at Akamai in the conference rooms on the second floor (200C/D).

Please join us for a night of Clojure related discussion and group activities.

Meet & Greet starts at 6:00. Group activities will begin at 6:30.

Future meeting ideas will be discussed over the meetup board and in our Google discussion group:  https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/boston-clojure .


Agenda for this meeting:

Presenter: Edward Sumitra

Ed Sumitra works as a Senior Full Stack Engineer at Curriculum Associates on both front end and the backend technologies. He uses Clojure based tools to work with large datasets and has recently discovered the conceptual simplicity in building Clojurescript web applications. He enjoys using technology to teach fun science and engineering to elementary school children and teaches in an after school program in Medford.

Title: Building ClojureScript web applications with React and Reagent


Abstract: Reagent is a popular ClojureScript library based on Facebook's React.js.  The presentation and demo will illustrate patterns for using Reagent and core.async to build modern web applications.

Outline:

1. React.js core concepts
2. Reagent core concepts
3. Adding behaviors and interactivity
4. Putting it all together in a web application
5. Advanced topics (time permitting)
results.how_to_find_us: Near the Kendall Square T stop
results.name: Building ClojureScript web applications with React and Reagent

results.description:
Join us for a leisurely sunset paddle on the Assabet River in Maynard and Stow. We'll paddle upstream, looking out for blue herons and other wildlife. As the sun sets, we'll paddle back to the cars. This is a slow-moving river, but you should be comfortable landing and getting out of your kayak into shallow water in low light.

Meet at the Maynard highway barn at the end of Winter St. Carry your boat 100 yards to the water and be ready to launch by 6:30. After you've unloaded your kayak, please park on the paved lot near the DPW yard so we're not blocking the bike path or the trail to the water.


Bring a headlamp or flashlight so that we can land and load our boats after sunset. If not everyone has a light, we'll head back earlier.

PFDs must be worn at all times on the water, and we'll paddle together as a group at a leisurely pace. There are no bathrooms at the launch (but plenty of gas stations and restaurants nearby in Maynard), and limited chances to land once we start paddling.

See you on the water!
results.name: Sunset Paddle on the Assabet River

For 20 years and counting, each summer the Foxboro Jaycees present a series of FREE concerts on the common. results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.

• It's at least a 3-hour drive both ways, so travelers would have to leave the Capital Region by 2:30-ish, return at about midnight.

•  Might be worth going earlier in the day and dinking around in the city.

• Don't know what parking costs

• The theater seats about 1,800, so it's big but not huge.

• Re: Ticketing. I only know the prices. Don't know whether seating is reserved, but I assume so, so the earlier the better on ticket buying.

results.description:
Hey BF! There is an event on June 11th at the Boston Children's museum called Grown Ups night! From the site: Break out your neon, your leg warmers, and your MC Hammer pants--for this one night only Boston Grown-Ups Museum is kickin it old school!

Ever wanted to visit Boston Children's Museum . . . without the children? To crawl to the top of our three-story Climb, blow a giant bubble, play in our Construction Zone, and rediscover your most playful self? Now is your chance!

On Thursday, June 11th, we're throwing open the doors to Boston Children's Museum to those who are young at heart. Come play in our groundbreaking exhibits while enjoying beer and wine plus tasty treats for purchase. Bring friends and meet new ones as you explore interactive exhibits, attempt to build a "big kid" sized fort, and explore your inner artist in the Art Studio. Stop into our Museum Shop and buy old favorites such as Pop Rocks, Pez dispensers and Gummy Worms.

Whether you were here as a kid or are new to town, Boston "Grown-Ups" Museum will bring out your innate sense of fun!

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-grown-ups-museum-tickets-16842346913

NOTE: There is a $25 cover. TL;DR - Shenanigans at the Children's Museum, $25 cover. Fun times to be had. Bring anyone and everyone!
results.name: Grown up night at BCM!

We'll run routes along the Charles River Greenway, Riverwalk, Newton and neighborhoods of Waltham, with options to extend for those who are looking to add distance (or end early!) Afterward we'll hop into the bar for post-run drinks. 

We meet in front of Shoppers Cafe and leave at 7:00p. There should be plenty of parking on the street and in the neighborhood. All levels are welcome, with a broad range of paces!

Runs are typically 3-5 miles. 

As our daylight becomes more limited, it is highly recommended to at least wear bright clothing, and also to consider bringing a reflective vest and/or lamp.  


See you there!

results.description:
Hi All -

It was great to see everyone who came out for our (overly rescheduled) Winter Meet Up at Ula. Thanks again to Korinn for hosting at her wonderful establishment - and putting out such a delightful arrangement of goodies and beverages. It was a great evening! 

Locally Owned is now collaborating with JP Local First to host these meetings on a more frequent basis.  Responsibility for the events will be shared between the two organizations and meeting frequency will increase to once every two months (from once per quarter). Thank you to all the JP Local First team members on this! 


The next event will be on THURSDAY, June 11th at Infrared5  (500 Amory Street, Suite 2). A few of the members had requested to have the event on a different night than Monday and we have listened. :)

Please be sure to RSVP so that we know how many are attending. Also, spread the word, invite other independent business owners - the more the merrier!

There will be an opportunity to share at this event. 

Looking forward to seeing you all soon.

Best -

Rebecca

results.description:
Experience the healing power of our interconnectedness through the field of the heart.  

Do you sometimes feel stressed, perhaps disconnected from yourself, and at times unable to relate to others?

According to the HeartMath® Institute, the electromagnetic field of the heart is a field of information that we can harvest to promote a collective state of well-being, peace and harmony. Let’s harvest and heal together!

Feel empowered and connected. Tap into your intuitive insights and heart intelligence. 

Anne-Marie was inspired by the findings of the HeartMath® Institute and after using it successfully with individuals, she developed this creative approach to working with small groups. She'll lead us, using guided imagery and Art Therapy (symbolic drawing), to access the healing potential of the field of our hearts. Together we’ll then be guided to harvest and benefit from the collective healing field of the group.   This will all be done in the safe, fun and relaxing atmosphere of our Heartbeat Salon group of 12-20 people!


About the group facilitator: Anne-Marie Campanella, MA has a Masters Degree in Art Therapy, and  over fifteen years of experience working in the mental health field in a clinical setting as well as at her home office. She offers individual and small group programs on a variety of topics using these same tools. She can be contacted at [masked] or[masked]-2524. Her website is <a>www.resonanceforlife.com.</a> 

Links

results.description:
Pub Trivia is a hit!  Let's try Stump trivia at 99 Restaurant next to Trader Joe's in Framingham!  Put your thinking caps on!  We're due for a big win!

 

A couple of notes:

1 - If we have a large group (more than 6 people) let's split into multiple teams.  This isn't a Stump Trivia rule.  It simply helps things be a little less crazy by having fewer people to discuss an answer.

2 - When I get to the restaurant I will ask the server if it will be possible to split the check for each individual who orders food/drink.  If the server indicates that they are not able to or that it will be a challenge for any reason, we will not insist on split checks.  I know everyone has passionate opinions about this.  Please respect this decision and do not make this challenging.

results.description:
The MFA is showing the complete works of offbeat Swedish director Roy Andersson this month. His films have been described as very dry black comedies. I haven't seen any of them, so I'll probably set up Meetups for each one.

The description of You, The Living, from the MFA website:
Filmmaker Roy Andersson draws the viewer into the world of a woman whose most uplifting moments are always balanced by tragedy, and whose joy is constantly offset by sorrow. In laughing at the good times and shedding a tear at the bad, the comic tragedy of life manifests itself in a manner that everyone can relate to.
results.name: Roy Andersson's You, The Living -- Quirky Swedish Art Film

results.description:
Three week Support Group: June 4, 11, 18

It takes 21-30 days to create new habits. You had a whole lot of information thrown at you this weekend. And a lot can get stirred up when we start moving this energy.


Receive support, review what you have learned, have your questions answered, and integrate what you have learned into your life!


• Review, reinforce and refine the tools and practices you learned


• Practice pranayam, white tantra yoga, bija mantras, working with energy, awakening the chakras, modalities of touch, and more...


• Receive weekly support to integrate these tools and practices into your life


• Have a safe, supportive space to discuss what arises for you doing the practices


• Share your insights and challenges

• Receive individualized attention


• Get your questions answers

• Create new habits of consciousness


• Develop increased trust, community and connection

Limited to 12. $30 each class, or 3 for $70* 

You may come to any of the sessions, even if you can't make them all. PLEASE RSVP TO EACH SESSION YOU PLAN TO ATTEND.


*If taking the whole series, RSVP for all three MeetUps. THIS WILL RESERVE YOUR SPOT. You will be charged $30 for each of the first two, and nothing for the last. And will pay the remaining $10 in person at first session.


This is only open to those who have attended the Beginner Seminar with Charles and Leah.

results.description:
What's that!? The non-stop thrills of ImprovBoston SketchHaus just keep rolling on? Yes, indeed: this week marks the live debut of Kaitlin Buckley's COMMUNITY TELEVISION. On Community Television, you're never quite sure what you're watching. Dive into the world of lovable weirdos who absolutely deserve to be on TV and have paid for the right to do so. THEN! You've seen them on the ImprovBoston Mainstage. You've seen them in the irrepressible improv team The Con Men. NOW: see Sam Ike and Conor Allen deliver live sketch comedy as only they can. It's off-the-wall, amped-up scripted funny stuff. It's IKE & ALLEN, and you're not going to miss a single second.

If you liked all that, why not stick around for the INCREDIBLY FREE sketch comedy open mic, Openhaus!? Bring your all-new, never-performed scripts and we'll act them out. Openhaus always a huge party, with incredibly supportive audiences and a lot of fun onstage. It's also free, but you can secure your spot in the lineup by grabbing a ticket to ImprovBoston SketchHaus!

With the utterly hilarious Xazmin Garza on hand to open up the night and host these two lunatic groups, this is a Thursday night jam-packed with wall-to-wall hooray!

(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

MUSEUM of FINE ARTS, BOSTON
Online mfa.org/music
Telephone[masked]
In person Visit any MFA ticket desk, 465 Huntington
Avenue, Boston, MA
M, T, Sat & Sun, 10 am-4:45 pm
W-F, 10 am-9:45pm

Curated by Darcy Kuronen, Pappalardo Curator of Musical Instruments for the MFA

Harry and Mildred Remis Auditorum, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
presented in partnership with Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts

The Golden Age of the Clavier
BEMF returns to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, for a remarkable showcase of exceptional artists and extraordinary instruments. Darcy Kuronen, Pappalardo Curator of Musical Instruments for the MFA and an internationally recognized authority on the history of musical instruments, has selected three carefully restored instruments from the 18th century for this very special event, including a German clavichord, French harpsichord, and English fortepiano. Don’t miss this chance to travel back in time and let these instruments share their musical secrets with you.

PART ONE: 10:30AM TO 12 NOON
ALEXANDER WEIMANN, harpsichord
featuring a 1736 French double-manual harpsichord by Henry Hemsch

Exploration 1735
One of the most sought-after ensemble directors, soloists, and chamber music partners of his generation, Mr. Weimann can be heard on some 100 CDs. Centerpieces of his lecture/demonstration recital will be Bach’s French Ouverture BWV 831, Rameau’s harpsichord arrangement of a suite from Les Indes galantes, and Handel’s 6 Grand Fugues (HWV 605–610), all compositions published within the year leading up to the most probable birth date of this famous instrument by German born and naturalized French harpsichord maker Henri Hemsch.

PART TWO: 12:30PM TO 2PM
TOM BEGHIN, fortepiano
featuring a 1796 English grand piano by John Broadwood & Son

Theresa Jansen: Pupil, Dedicatee, and Composer
Renowned both as a groundbreaking scholar and brilliantly eloquent performer, fortepianist Tom Beghin has performed to acclaim around the world. His monumental recording project, The Virtual Haydn, has been hailed as a genuinely revolutionary artistic and technical accomplishment. For his BEMF début, Tom Beghin highlights the ambitious concert culture of 1790s London by celebrating one of its star pianists, Theresa Jansen, to whom Haydn and Clementi dedicated grand sonatas. These works, and her own compositions, are performed on a 1796 fortepiano from England’s preeminent keyboard maker, John Broadwood & Son.

PART THREE: 2:30PM TO 4PM
LUC BEAUSÉJOUR, clavichord
featuring a 1796 German Clavichord by Johann Christoph Georg Schiedmayer

Canadian keyboard virtuoso Luc Beauséjour has been hailed across North America and Europe for the elegance and expressiveness of his playing. Highlights of his recital, performed on one of the fewer than one dozen surviving clavichords by master builder Johann Christoph Georg Schiedmayer of Stuttgart, include Handel’s Suite in D minor and Bach’s French Suite No. 5 in G major, BWV 816.

Alexander Weimann

Tom Beghin

Luc Beauséjour
results.name: BEMF-Keyboard Mini-Festival

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Please read disclaimer at the bottom of the page before you RSVP

Who can come
Everybody is invited.
I will be skippering the boat in and out of the mooring field and will be taking over when needed. Once we are in clear waters we will be taking turns at the tiller.


Where
We will be sailing in the Boston inner harbor, and might venture out and sail around one of the Boston Harbor Islands.


What
we will sail on
Boston 27 (Based on Soling) , Sonar, or Soling. You can learn more about these boats here: http://www.bostonharborsailing.com/fleet_boston27.html


to expect
A laid back and safe sailing adventure to the extent it is possible on the racing boat without the engine or bathroom in the busy harbor.

In perfect conditions Boston 27 is a comfortable boat to sail on, but in the strong winds boat will lean and you might get splashed. On a windy day be prepared to pull on the ropes, move around, get splashed, and not have much down-time.

Be warned that it can get stressful at times and we will need to react quickly. Here are some common stressful situations: Drifting towards other boats on the mooring field, drifting towards shore, not being able to grab a hold of the mooring rope, getting yelled at by the coast guard patrol, getting stuck in the middle of the harbor. Remember, these boats don’t have engines and we will have to rely on the wind power. During stressful situations it is important to stay calm and to work as a team.


will be on the boat
Two flotation pillows and four life jackets.


is important
Safety will be our number one priority. I will give a safety crash course once we are on the boat. I recommend that everyone wears a life jacket.


to bring
Sunscreen, hat, sunglasses, water, and a cell phone. Sailing Boston 27 or Soling on a windy day can get you splashed. I would recommend bringing a change of clothes and getting a waterproof case for you cell phone or wrapping it in a plastic bag.


I will bring
My own gear, two-way UHF floating radio pre-programmed with the sailing club and Coast Guard channels and a winch handle to help tighten the sails.


Important Disclaimer
Sailing can be and will be stressful at times.
It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is considered part of the sport.

For New Members AND NON-Members:

For every sailor who walks through our door, start here! This FREE Orientation class will get you familiar with how everything works at CBI. The orientation class is the gateway to everything that CBI has to offer, whether you’re a seasoned sailor or brand new to boats. Done entirely on the dock, your orientation will include a guided tour of CBI’s boats and facilities, an overview of our classes and programs, as well as plenty of time to ask the questions that matter to you as a sailor. All orientations meet at the base of the American Flag Pole out on the dock, and runs for about half an hour. All are welcome to this class!


Afterwards, we invite you to meet one another and ask about other Orientation class attendees' prior experience with sailing. Perhaps you can find a friend to take the Beginner Sailing classes together with once you join. 

Friday Nights are also when CBI members go out for Informal Racing, so it is an exciting night to watch the sailors and learn more about how you can progress your skills after learning to sail. Certainly ask your Orientation instructor about the Friday Night Informal Racing and Informal Instruction if he or she does not mention it. If you have any questions, please feel free to post below!

Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a free seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, will even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Join us on Friday, June 12th, as DJ/Producer Danny Satori presents a free workshop on the process & challenges of releasing a record in 2015. Following the debut release of his original work, ‘Morning Sun,’ on Krafted Records with a remix by Brazil’s Daniel Secco, Danny will touch on topics including tips on DAW workflow, connecting with record labels, and integration of Eastern practices to guide aspiring DJs/Producers through the jungle of infinite possibilities. Free admission, and all levels are welcome to participate. Beatport Release: https://pro.beatport.com/release/morning-sun/1496891

Krafted Music: http://www.kraftedmusic.com/

Artist Profile: Daniel Secco ~ https://soundcloud.com/djdanielsecco

Whether it be performing Liszt repertoire at New England Conservatory’s coveted Jordan Hall, or live hybrid DJing & music production of deep, sexy house music for UK’s Krafted Music Group - Danny “Satori” Kutty is no stranger to the pursuit of artistic expression. Praised for “bringing the marble back to life,” he now maintains a performance standard on the piano of concert repertoire & improvisation inspired by the ever-changing universe. As a DJ/Producer, his multi-faceted blends of House Music, Old-
School Hip-Hop, and World Lounge have made him an established performance artist in nightlife at venues such as the A.R.T.’s Club Oberon, RISE::Boston’s After-Hours Dance Club, & Santos Party House. To learn more about Danny, check out his website at www.dannykutty.com.

results.description:
Let your heart sing!
Do you love to sing, but…?
Do you yearn to step into fuller expression? To be heard? To hear yourself? In a circle tradition, and with love and acceptance, we will sing songs of inspiration and gently embrace and allow our voices to express from within. It doesn’t matter how you sound, because this is about
• the energy that flows (and doesn’t care if we’re in tune),
• opening a door to your heart and giving it wings to express,
• bringing the wisdom of many song traditions into our daily lives, and
• the power of supportive community.
In a SpiritSong circle, we learn to listen deeply and open to the beautiful spaces within, and we are heard without judgment. We cultivate authentic expression. We share in the healing joy of sound!

You are warmly invited to join us at our monthly drop-in, 7-9 pm, Friday, June 12th in Stow, MA.
Sign-up here to reserve your place.
Led by Carolyn Sprague, certified SpiritSong Facilitator (trained by Shawna Carol).
Hosted by MariePatrice Masse of Inspiring Life.
Call or email MariePatrice for more info: [masked][masked]-0897.
Heartfelt Donations appreciated.

The Philosophy of Confucius emphasized personal and governmental morality, correctness of social relationships, justice and sincerity. For reflection: 

1. Everything has its beauty but not everyone sees it. 

2. Ignorance is the night of the mind, but a night without moon and star.

3. If a man takes no thought about what is distant, he will find sorrow near at hand. 

4. They must often change who would be constant in happiness or wisdom.

There is more to life than what we think…

Come find out for yourself.
results.name: Meet the Philosophers: an evening with Confucius

After experiencing a deep healing, you will align all your major energy centers (chakras) as well as your Soul (akash) and your Over Soul (highest self). 

We will explore the etheric realms (star nations) and if you choose to at the time, receive energy, frequency and information that will serve you and your highest and greatest good at this time.  We will then as a group send the acquired and created by the group - down into the Heart of Gaia - sharing the goodness with every living things on this planet!  And rippling out into all areas of our own lives!

All levels are welcome!  No experience is necessary - only an openness to the process and unlimited benefits this work!

Feelin’ the night fever? Come celebrate Summer with a trip down to funky town! Grab some vintage threads, string up those neon lights, and get ready to boogie ‘cause Bike Party is turning this city into a disco inferno. We’ll start hustlin’ at 7:30pm and keep groovin’ all night long!

Check out our Facebook Event Page to see who else is coming (nearly 500 people signed up so far!)

Suggest songs on the Spotify Collaborative Playlist  

Check out our --> Lookbook <-- for inspiration on what to wear.

Route: TBA (about 10 miles, with a few party stops to get groovy)


After party: Beach Party in South Boston!

If you've never been to a Boston Bike Party you should expect a slow paced ride, following the rules of the road. If the weather is good, there will be a few hundred riders. It's a social event with lots of friendly people. The ride starts at Copley Square, and will go a few miles to the first party stop, then a few more miles to the second party stop, and few more miles to the final party stop which will be in South Boston at the beach.  Check out this video for a sense of the experience. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tJot-D1S6T4

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the building.  The stairs will bring you to the door.
results.name: (Newton) Intermediate Longsword, Dagger and Grappling

results.description:
Learn how to meditate at Diamond Way Buddhist center of Boston. This Friday we have the wonderful opportunity to learn from Diamond Way Buddhist Teacher Jeff Su!


Friday June 12th, 2015

7:45 pm Doors Open
8:00 pm Lecture
9:00 pm Guided Meditation on the 16th Karmapa


What Is Buddhist Meditation?

In Buddhism, meditation means "effortlessly remaining in what is".

This state may be brought about by calming and holding the mind, when compassion and wisdom are realized, or by working with our bodies' energy channels and meditating on light forms of Buddhas.

We begin the evening with a basic introduction to Diamond Way Buddhism. This is the perfect time to come if you have not been to our center before. Your host will spend about a half hour explaining the basics of Diamond Way meditation and you will have time to ask any questions you may have.

About Us

Diamond Way Buddhist Group of Boston belongs to an international non-profit network of over 600 lay Diamond Way Buddhist centers of the Karma Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism, founded by Lama Ole Nydahl and under the spiritual guidance of H.H. the 17th Gyalwa Karmapa, Trinley Thaye Dorje.

Diamond Way Buddhism offers practical and effective methods to realize mind’s inherent richness for the benefit of all. With an accessible and modern style, it works with people’s confidence and desire, using every situation in life to develop fearlessness and joy. We always present a basic introduction for newcomers, and the meditations are guided in English.

To learn more about our center visit:
http://www.diamondway.org/boston/

Street parking is available on the corner of Rockingham and Granite street and along Granite.  There is also a large parking lot with a Trader Joe's 2 minutes walk away from the center.  

29 Rockingham Street

Cambridge, MA 02139

Telephone:[masked]

web: http://www.diamondway.org/boston/

email: [masked]

results.description:
Half Polish-half Colombian guitarist Stash (short for Stanislaw) Wyslouch grew up on heavy metal before submerging himself in bluegrass and country music. His history in hard rock still manifests itself in his propensity for wringing unexpected sounds out of his guitar and belting at the top of his vocal range.

https://scontent-iad.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xap1/v/t1.0-9/1239914_1108375025845318_4966278069475076153_n.jpg?oh=9b746183b1a281c833491f3671c00e8f&oe=560AD468

Since graduating from the Berklee College of Music in 2010 Stash has been touring full-time with the progressive bluegrass band, Rounder Recording Artists The Deadly Gentlemen having released two albums as guitarist and singer of the group, "Carry me to Home" (2011) and "Roll me, Tumble Me" (2013). His resume also includes membership in The Boston Boys, Blue Moose and the Unbuttoned Zippers, and a US-State department sponsored tour with The Earth Stringband in 2011, being the first all-American band to play in the country of Timor-Leste.


With Blue Moose and the Unbuttoned Zippers in Joliette, QC at the Memoires et Racines festival July 2012

Stash has played at many well-known festivals and venues including Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival (Oak Hill, NY), Old Settler's Music Festival (Austin, TX), Northwest String Summit (Portland, OR), DelFest (Cumberland, MD), Rockygrass (Lyons, CO), Big Sky Big Grass (Big Sky, MT), Merlefest (Wilkesboro, NC), Savannah Music Festival (Savannah, GA), River City Roots (Missoula, MT) among some of them. His touring career has taken him across the globe to Sweden, Denmark, the UK, Germany, Czech Republic, Austria, Switzerland, Timor-Leste, Thailand, Cambodia, Korea, Japan and Laos.

Stash has shared the stage with The Del McCoury band, David Grisman, The Yonder Mountain Stringband, Sarah Jarosz, Chris Thile, Peter Rowan, Michael Daves, Darol Anger, Greensky Bluegrass, The Infamous Stringdusters, and more. After nearly a decade of touring and recording, Stash is working on his first solo release as a band leader delivering his unique and edgy blend of heavy metal and American roots music, to be released in the Summer of 2015.

Stash and the SoulKrushers are
Stash Wyslouch - guitar
Duncan Wickel - fiddle
Noam Wiesenberg - bass
Sean Trischka - percussion
www.stashwyslouch.com www.facebook.com/stashwyslouchmusic

5/21: Lineup change, Bronwyn Keith-Hynes will be replacing Duncan Wickel.A former Virginia state fiddle champ, Bronwyn is a worthy replacement.


$10 general admission, $8 seniors and students. Tickets are available through Eventbrite - http://www.eventbrite.com/e/stash-and-the-soulkrushers-tickets-16846893512. As the room capacity is 35, we strongly recommend purchasing as soon as possible.


p.s. The venue is BYO-friendly.


========
Founded in 2007, notloB Music has presented more than 150 folk, old-time, blue grass, string band and Celtic concerts in unique venues throughout the greater Boston area.
Website - https://sites.google.com/site/notlobmusic/
Mailing list - http://eepurl.com/4_XMX
Twitter - https://twitter.com/notlobpresents

results.name: Stash and the SoulKruhers

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us again THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join me for a beginner west coast swing class from 8:30-9:15pm (Experienced with WCS? Join Marcus Schwarz for the Intermediate class at 8:30!). If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-11pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Beginner & Intermediate West Coast Swing Class & Social Dance!

results.description:
Don't you like to help your local community? 

Wouldn't you like to easily meet new people? 

Please join the Boston Volunteers to build a new community playground!  When you show up on Saturday morning, you will see a large area of dirt.  Throughout the day, you will assemble individual pieces of equipment (swings, slides, climbing walls, monkey bars, and more), carry equipment into place, pour concrete, and lay down wood carpet.  You will also enjoy music, a BBQ, and other entertainment.  By sunset, a full playground will be constructed and prepared for 100 children to play. 

Everyone 16 and over is welcome!  No construction experience or skill required--you will be supervised and coached by experienced builders.  You do not need to be in great physical shape--there are many tasks that do not require any carrying or lifting.  Please make sure to wear sunscreen and a smile!

A couple popular Meetups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Do you like adventuring: Boston Adventurers

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Restaurants

This will be a very popular special volunteer event. 

There are very limited spots. Can you grab a spot?

Refreshing BBQ and Live Music will be provide for you. 


We hope you can join us! 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the popular group of volunteers. I'll provide my cell for your convenience!
results.name: Hand on Helping Boston's Kids. Build a Playground 4 Kids + FREE BBQ &Live Music!
