results.description:
Please join us for the run even if you missed the previous run. We will be doing about 4 to 8 miles this time depending on your target race. Please make sure to RSVP if you are coming and arrive on time to avoid missing the briefing. Note the special tips below to avoid parking tickets. 

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. Our coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises.

Registration fees:  If you have not yet registered and paid the fees, please do so at this page.  http://www.teamaidasha.org/register  Please contact us at [masked] if you have any questions.

Nearest T-stop: Davis Square, Red Line. Look for the Au Bon Pain building when you get out of the station. 

If you are driving: Please try to arrive 5-10 minutes earlier to find a parking spot. You can find free parking spots on the Holland Street if you drive a few blocks from Au Bon Pain towards Hodgkins Park. You can also find metered parking spots near Au Bon Pain. Remember to feed the meter to avoid getting ticket.

Mid-week runs: Our coach recommends that we all do at least two (if possible three) mid-week runs, three miles each. Mid-week runs stay at the low mileage, only Saturday runs will gradually increase in mileage. You may be able to find running buddies who live/work close to you from our group for your mid-week runs. 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs. 
If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here. 
http://www.teamaidasha.org/information-session-materials.html 

Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at:http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html 

About AID-Boston 
Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at:www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT 
Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at:http://www.ashanet.org/mit/ 

Questions? : Email us at [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a group of runners and volunteers
results.name: Beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training run June 13th

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be by the Lifeguard house
results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
Founders Day is an annual celebration of the town's birthday. It offers a parade, food, music, activities for kids, and even fireworks!

More info can be found at http://www.foxboroughfoundersday.com/

Are you planning on attending Foxborough Founders Day? Be sure to check out the various offerings by the Foxboro Jaycees that day!

Would you like to help us for a few hours with our various activities that day? We can use volunteers from pretty much 9am-3pm and 7pm-10pm! And we need a lot of helpers to pull all our events off!

The Jaycees Concession Stand on Booth Field is serving lunch! Serving Hamburgers, Cheeseburgers, Hot Dogs, Italian Sausages, Salt potatoes, and water & soda. This year, we are also planning on selling Kettle Corn.

Stop by out our membership booth at the event to find out more about us! You may even win a free Foxboro Jaycees membership for a year!

If you are around for the fireworks (9:15pm-ish), be sure to purchase glow items from the Foxboro Jaycees!

Founders Day projects are important fundraisers for the Foxboro Jaycees that will help fund several community programs they coordinate, such as the Annual Easter Egg Hunt, Caroling on the Common, Holiday Decorations for the Common, Bandstand Repair, Fruit Baskets for the Foxboro Discretionary Fund, Sand for Seniors, and other local causes they support.

Find out more at <a>www.foxborojaycees.org.</a>

results.description:
Event Organizer: John (LAG) Lagasse @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to climb Old Speck (4,180 feet - #3 on the AMC ME 4K List) the third highest peak in Maine and is located in Grafton Notch State Park. Atop the wooded summit is an observation tower that provides magnificent views in every direction.


If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list and I will add people that answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are permitted only with prior approval of the organizer. I don't usually allow dogs so do not let me regret it. :)


=== Trip Summary ===

On this slow/moderate pace trip we will hike about 7.8 miles and climb about 2,800 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 30 minutes to complete though I'm planning on 8 hours. This event is considered Moderate/Intermediate because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:


</a><a href="http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Old-Speck-Mountain/forecasts/1270">http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Old-Speck-Mountain/forecasts/1270

=== What to Bring ===

Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

Basic Direction:  http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&geocode=&saddr=boston+ma&daddr=44.596335,-70.945587&mra=dme&mrcr=0&mrsp=1&sz=10&sll=44.406316,-71.065063&sspn=0.662219,1.1975...


We will be leaving the trailhead at 9:00 AM at the Grafton Notch State Park parking lot. The lot is located on the west side of Route 26 about 12 miles north of Route 2 in North Newry, ME. According to Google Maps it is about 194 miles and should take about 3 hours 22 minutes to get there from Boston.

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: ME4K - OLD SPECK (Moderate/Intermediate)

results.description:
Meet at the entrance to the museum where you can buy coffee. If you think you see a meetup person, ask them.

We'll go to the Museum which is free on this Saturday. Bring your interesting car to park on the lawn to be admired by spectators. Or park in the free parking lot. We'll be joining other car enthusiasts who we can ask about the fine cars on exhibit as we sip coffee. Then we'll go for a walk on the grounds about 2 miles.


Cars and Coffee:

http://larzanderson.org/events/lawn-events/carscoffee/


Closest T station is Forest Hills, 1.1  mile walk.

Cars and Coffee was created for car enthusiasts to meet up early on a Saturday morning. The Museum opens early at 8am on these designated Saturdays for your viewing. Grab a coffee, a snack and check out some of the Boston area’s best cars.

This event is free, but if you become a member, it includes free admission to all the Museum’s lawn events. http://larzanderson.org/events/lawn-events/carscoffee2014/

--

The Museum is housed in the opulent carriage house first built by wealthy Bostonians Larz and Isabel Anderson. It is now home to the Anderson Motorcar Collection as well as revolving exhibits featuring rare automobiles, automobilia, automotive artwork and vintage fashion. These exhibitions are a feast for the eyes and provide a great educational experience for both kids and adults.

Just ten minutes from downtown Boston and nestled inside the 64 beautiful acres of Larz Anderson Park, the Museum is home to “America’s Oldest Car Collection”. These automobiles form the Museum’s permanent collection and are housed within the Carriage House, built in 1888 and designed by the city architect of Boston, Edmund M. Wheelwright, who was also responsible for several notable Boston structures like the Boston Public Library.
results.name: Brookline: Larz Anderson Car Museum: Cars & Coffee (free)

venue.name: Mass Audubon's Drumlin Farm Wildlife Sanctuary

results.description:
June is National Dairy Month, so help Mass Audubon celebrate by volunteering at Drumlin Farm for their Dairy Day Festival!  Their barns will be open on this special day for up-close access to our favorite dairy animals and the tasty treats they help them produce. All proceeds support our education and conservation programs.

Volunteers will help at the cooking demo, serve ice cream, hand out dairy samples, assist visitors with crafts and games…



Event Highlights


• Watch milking demonstrations, and try milking on your own at their practice stations

• Crafts and games for kids in their Get Moovin’ zone

• Cheese, butter, and ice cream making demonstrations

• Up-close viewing of their heritage breed cattle

• Free hayrides to celebrate the crowning of the Drumlin Farm Dairy Princess

• Purchase lunch made with Drumlin Farm veggies from their guest food truck: Posto Mobile of Somerville

• Enjoy local ice cream generously sponsored by Reasons to Be Cheerful in Concord

VOLUNTEER INFORMATION: 

Please arrive a little before 9:30. 

Volunteers are asked to park at Mass Audubon Headquarters. Drumlin Farm and Mass Audubon Headquarters have the same street address but are across the road from each other. Headquarters is on the north side of route 117 and the entrance is slightly east of Drumlin Farm’s. Once you have parked at headquarters, carefully cross route 117 and go across the dirt path to the paved drive. Follow the driveway to the right – meet at the Pond House.

Come to the Pond House  – this is the small blue building across from the Drumlin Farm gift shop and located just past the Nature Center. The Drumlin Farm Volunteer Coordinator - Pam Sowizral - will meet us there.

More details about the event can be found on their website at http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/drumlin-farm/news-events/dairy-day

results.description:
Join us for a paddle on the Ipswich River.  This slow moving  river runs through forests, meadows and wetlands and much of the area is protected or undeveloped.  We'll pass Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary and the Bradley Palmer State Park. Much of the river is accessible only by canoe or kayak and is considered a paradise for birders and naturalists.  We've seen a good variety of birds when we've done this trip in prior years.

We'll meet at Foote Brothers Canoe in Ipswich Mass.  We'll be taking the 10AM  shuttle 8 miles upstream to our put in point (Salem Run/Rt.97). We'll plan to take about 6-7 hours paddling downstream, including time for a couple of stops for lunch, a swim, and a stroll.

Foote Brothers rents canoes ($42) and kayaks ($42) or you can bring your own ($12 shuttle fee per person).  Kayak rentals go fast so reserve early. Call Foote Brother's directly for boat reservations (978) 356-9771. 


Remember to bring insect repellent, sunscreen, water, snacks, lunch and to wear shoes that you don't mind getting wet.  Also, remember your PFD etc if you are bringing your own boat.

No dogs please.


Please visit the Foote Brother's web site for directions and other information:
http://footebrotherscanoes.com/contact-us/

 
Thunder/lightning will cancel this trip (decision made the day before the trip).  You must cancel your boat reservation if we cancel.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet at the rental facility.  I'll send an email the day before the trip with my cell phone number.
results.name: Paddle the Ipswich River

group.name: Merrimack Valley Women: Outdoors and About

results.description:
ADVANCED LIGHTING TECHNIQUES

this  workshop goes way beyond the basic Clamshell lighting set-up and is intended to teach you more advanced techniques that will cover:

Lighting ratios 

Additive and Subtractive lighting effects


Feathering the light


Hair lights


Gels and their purpose


Gobos and Flags 


Using Grids and egg-crates


The beauty dish and how to use it.


Class will run from 10am until 4pm approx with a break in the middle for lunch. 

You will need a digital SLR and lens ( any will suffice). All other lighting equipment and triggers will be provided. 

To attend this class you must be comfortable setting your camera's Aperture, ISO, and Speed . We will be working solely in Manual mode and no instruction on setting your camera will be provided.  

The remote triggers provided will work with all DSLR brands, however some Sony cameras may need a converter to enable the hotshot to become a standard size.
results.how_to_find_us: Call 339-499-8506 if lost
results.name: Advanced Lighting Techniques

results.description:
Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at City Sports on Comm Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com


Read the BLOG

results.description:
Workshop for Developing Mediums with International Psychic Medium Joanne Gerber﻿

First Spiritualist Church of Quincy, 40 West Street, Quicy, MA 02169, 10 AM to 4:00PM.﻿

Class Fee: $70. Class size limited to 28 students.

To register for this workshop, please email First Spiritualist Church of Quincy at [masked]﻿

"Joanne Gerber raised the bar for me in a way that just made it harder for other mediums to get on my list. She filled my hour with evidence of an afterlife. Every medium on my list has their niche that made them stand out among the hundreds I’ve tested. Joanne’s is nonstop messages from deceased loved ones, which include physical descriptions, personalities, past memories, current events, names, dates and ages." ~ Bob Olson

Join us for this intense mediumship workshop dedicated to helping you develop and gain personal excellence with your mediumship. This workshop will stretch any boundaries, and you will learn a new sense of confidence with your mediumship. We will experiment with various exercises/meditations, private sittings, public platform, and scientific tools used to test and study psychic energy and afterlife communication. This workshop is for mixed levels, but only for those who have had prior practice through development circle or classes.

Joanne Gerber is an internationally known and scientifically certified psychic medium and spiritual teacher with over fourteen years of professional teaching experience. For more information about Joanne, please visit her website at:www.joannegerber.com – Also see the article about Bob Olson's experience with Joanne.
results.name: Raising the Bar:  Achieving Personal Excellence with Your Mediumship

group.name: The First Spiritualist Church of Quincy

results.name: Saturday Soccer!

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description:
Summer begins in Topsfield!

Saturday, June 13th marks the beginning of summer with the Topsfield Historical Society’s major fundraising event: The Annual Strawberry Festival. Bowls and bowls of fresh strawberries, whipped cream and piles of shortcakes are prepared and served by volunteer members. Now is the time to plan ahead for graduation, wedding and holiday gifts. There are over 70 fine artisans displaying beautiful handcrafted one-of-a-kind items such as jewelry, pottery, paintings, and woodcrafts. You can browse through the latest donations to the popular Friends of the Library Book Sale. There are plenty of games for the kids, sponsored by the Masconomet Soccer Team, and live music to tap you toes to from the picturesque Gazebo.

Free Admission and Plenty of Free Parking
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the Gazebo
results.name: Topsfield Strawberry Festival

results.description:
Don't you like to help your local community? 

Wouldn't you like to easily meet new people? 

Please join the Boston Volunteers to build a new community playground!  When you show up on Saturday morning, you will see a large area of dirt.  Throughout the day, you will assemble individual pieces of equipment (swings, slides, climbing walls, monkey bars, and more), carry equipment into place, pour concrete, and lay down wood carpet.  You will also enjoy music, a BBQ, and other entertainment.  By sunset, a full playground will be constructed and prepared for 100 children to play.

Everyone 16 and over is welcome!  No construction experience or skill required--you will be supervised and coached by experienced builders.  You do not need to be in great physical shape--there are many tasks that do not require any carrying or lifting.  Please make sure to wear sunscreen and a smile!

A couple popular Meetups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Do you like adventuring: Boston Adventurers

This will be a very popular special volunteer event. 

There are very limited spots. Can you grab a spot?

Refreshing BBQ and Live Music will be provide for you. 

We hope you can join us! 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the popular group of volunteers. I'll provide my cell for your convenience!
results.name: Hand on Helping Boston's Kids. Build a Playground 4 Kids + FREE BBQ &Live Music!

results.description:
Hello All,
2nd Monthly walk at Borderlands.   I'd like to do the Pond Walk/Tisdale Road which is about 3.1 miles. If anyone is interested afterwards, we can also walk the short but more challenging West Side Trail(about 20-25 min).   Please be advised that parking has increased from $2 to $5 for residents, $6 for non-residents. :( The walk starts at 10:30 but will wait 10 minutes if there are late-comers.  Please meet in front of the visitor's center.

Directions

Borderland is located approximately three miles from the center of Sharon, Mansfield and North Easton, Massachusetts; the park is twenty miles from Boston and thirty miles from Providence, RI.

From north: Take Rte. 128 south to Rte. 95 south (towards Providence). Take exit 10 (Sharon, Walpole and Coney Street). Take a left at the end of the ramp and follow this road, two or three miles to the traffic lights in Sharon Center. Go straight thru this intersection and immediately bear right onto Pond St. Follow Pond St. for 1-1/2 miles until you come to a traffic rotary. Go half way around the rotary and continue onto Massapoag Ave. for three miles to the park entrance, on your left.

From Boston: Take the southeast expressway south to Rte. 128 north and then to Rte. 95 south. Follow directions from above.

From West: Mass Pike to Rte. 495 south to exit 10 (Easton and Rte. 123). Take a left at the end of the ramp and follow Rte. 123 east towards Easton. Rte. 123 will merge with Rte. 106 east. After this merge look for the brown "Borderland" sign, on the left about a half mile from the merge. Take this left onto Poquanticut Ave. After about a mile the road will fork, bear to the left onto Massapoag Ave. and follow the signs to the park, approximately another two miles. Entrance will be on your right.
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet in front of the Visitors Center
results.name: Enjoy 3 mile walk thru Borderlands State Park

results.description:
Posta di Donna, the Lady's Guard, is the most versatile of Fiore's longsword positions, allowing every attack and multiple defenses.  Our class Posta di Donne, the Ladies' Guardpost, is an opportunity to learn the foundations of Fiore's system of swordfighting, dagger, and unarmed fighting in company with other interested women.


Around[masked], Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.  Armizare strikes to the gaps and the openings of your opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.


Our basic Foundational course will be taught by Deborah and Nelly, Armizare practitioners and teachers.  These four linked classes give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enable women to begin regular training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.


Whether you're new to swordfighting or looking for a good excuse to come back, come and join the Armizare Amazons!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (June 13, 20, 27, and July 11)  and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)
results.name: Posta di Donne : Women's Foundational Fiore Course (Cambridge/Arlington)

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description:
The chances are good that you're reading this because you've been wanting more out of life.  

The best thing you can invest in is the continuing development of your mind and body to accomplish any goal and overcome any challenge in life.

Come in for a free trial lesson today!

When training towards one’s Black Belt, students study themselves while studying 3 internal, 3 external and 2 weapons martial arts styles that encompass all the major principles of all other martial arts (Kong Su Do (Karate/Tae Kwon Do), Aikido/Hapkido, Udo (Judo), Kung Fu, Bagua Zhang, Tai Chi, Kom Do (Samurai Sword), and Ship Pal Gye (traditional Chinese weapons training)).


Have the martial arts lifestyle — go anywhere, do anything, and be free to have everything you want from life.  Start today!

1 weeks of free adult training at the Stoneham location only.

Visit our Body Mind Systems Training Centers :

results.description:
Since it'll be high 70's and almost 80's this Saturday, a handful of us will be going to Nantasket Beach, so feel free to come join us for some Good Fun and Good Company!


We will start off with some Stand Up Paddle Boarding or Kayaking. You can choose one or the other. We went last year and had lots of fun! No worries, you don't have to be an expert and it's really not that hard at all! Plus you will be provided Life Vests. Beginners are welcomed!

Afterwards, we will head on over to the Beach area to Wade and Dip our Toes in the Water, Swim in the Ocean, Soak in the Sun, Throw Frisbees and Footballs, and fully enjoy Summer finally! We look forward in seeing you on our fun Summer Adventure!

PICTURES FROM THE LAST THREE BEACH EVENTS:

Beach Event 01: http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Asian-Professionals/photos/24064832/406358522/


Beach Event 02: http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Asian-Professionals/photos/23142832/387713502/ </a>

Beach Event 03: <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Asian-Professionals/photos/23707672/#[masked]">http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Asian-Professionals/photos/23707672/395774392/

IMPORTANT NOTE: Please try your best to be on time as it would be quite hard to find each other on the Beach and the Cellular Reception there is Quite Poor.

WHERE TO MEET: We will meet in front of Grand Chinatown Restaurant in Quincy at 11:30am and head from there. Reception at the Beach is Poor and you'll have to past the restaurant anyways to get to the beach, thus the meeting point.

MBTA: You can get off at North Quincy Station on the Red Line via Braintree Line and walk down the street for 3 minutes to Grand Chinatown Restaurant. Then we can carpool from there.

CARPOOL: Please indicate if you need or can give a ride. And which town you need to be picked up from or can pick up from. Thanks!

DESTINATION / GPS ADDRESS: Nantasket Kayaks, Located at Steamboat Wharf Marina, 48 George Washington Blvd. Hull, MA 02045

PARKING: Last year, Parking was available for Free if you pay for Stand Up Paddle Boarding / Kayaking. Parking is also available for around $10 if the Free Parking Lot is full. Street Parking is available if you can find a space and it's Free, but I believe it’s only limited to 2 hours.

AFTER BEACH FUN: We will be treating ourselves to some Sweet Desserts at Kozy Desserts in Quincy after our Day of Beach Fun and will have FREE Karaoke available for those who purchase a Dessert. The Owner will also be giving our group a Special 20% off Discount!  :D

-Xiao

results.description:
Cape Cod Canal bike ride. Alot of people seem to enjoy this comfortable ride. All flat, all bike types welcome. 14 miles r/t. Plenty of free parking. 

Bike Path Map:

http://www.nae.usace.army.mil/Portals/74/docs/Recreation/CCCRecMap.pdf


Parking:

Park at the Buzzards Bay Recreation Area side. There is a huge parking lot and free. This one is off of Main Street. Use 100 Main Street as the gps location, Krua Thai Restaurant. It may say Bourne Mass too on your gps. 

**Bring plenty of water, snacks, helmet, and pump up your tires!**  


When I drive down there, I go by way of I-495 S to rt 25 then get off a side road. Because traffic can be horrible when getting closer to the Bourne Bridge. 

I will leave updates on this site, it is better to get a hold of me on this site rather than an indiv. email.

**Remember if you can not make it change your rsvp instead of leaving a message on here.** It's more respectful and less characters you have to press on the keyboard. I will keep up with the weather and hopefully it does not rain. Weather so far has been good to me on these rides and have not had to cancel too much. But I will post it on here as well. Sometimes if it rains in Boston it doesn't always mean it's raining down the cape.
results.name: Cape Cod Canal

results.description:
Social In Boston Presents:

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Second Stop...

The Rattlesnake opened its doors in the Back Bay in 1990, occupying the small second floor and roof deck at 384 Boylston Street. Within three years, The Rattlesnake was so popular that the owners expanded operations to occupy the first floor, more than doubling capacity.

Today, Poe’s Kitchen at The Rattlesnake is open seven days a week to serve lunch, dinner, and myriad specialty drinks. The outdoor roof deck is open to the public April through October (and when the weather cooperates during the rest of the year), accommodating 50 people with a full bar and menu available. New to the Rattlesnake is the street level outdoor patio.

Join us on the roof deck to eat lunch, relax, and savor an experience like no other!

On the menu: Click here for the menu.

GETTING THERE

Rattlesnake Bar is at 384 Boylston Street, Boston, 02116.

Click here for <a>directions on Google</a>. The nearest T stops are Arlington Station on the Green Line.

Parking: There is on street parking if you can find it, otherwise, check this Google map for parking near The Rattlesnake.

See you there Socialites!

~Matt
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us on the Roof Deck! : )

results.description:
While I haven't been to Lynn Woods from what I've heard it's pretty techy. If you have pads this is probably the place to use them.

Directions from nemba website: Get on I95 North. Take exit 44B for Lynn, Rt 129 East. This will dump you on a rotary, just continue to follow the signs for Rt 129 east. After you go about two more miles, a small road will go off to your right, which will be marked with a sign for the Larry Gannon Municipal Golf Course. Follow this road for about 200 yards until it dead ends into a parking lot with a baseball field on the side. This is the entrance to Lynn Woods. About 200 feet off the end of the parking lot will be the tail end of Walden Pond. To the left is the bulk of the reservation, including Dungeon Rock. To the right is the technical terrain that makes Lynn Woods awesome. Leave a lot of time and try both!
results.name: Let's Explore Lynn Woods

results.description:
THE BOOK:

Malgudi Days by R.K. Narayan

DESCRIPTION:

Introducing this collection of stories, R. K. Narayan describes how in India 'the writer has only to look out of the window to pick up a character and thereby a story'. Malgudi Days is the marvellous result. Here Narayan portrays an astrologer, a snake-charmer, a postman, a vendor of pies and chappatis - all kinds of people, drawn in full colour and endearing domestic detail. And under his magician's touch the whole imaginary city of Malgudi springs to life, revealing the essence of India and of human experience.  <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/14082.Malgudi_Days#"></a>

NOTES:

There are 12 copies in the Minuteman Library System.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the book on the table
results.name: JUNE: Malgudi Days by RK Narayan at Punjabi Grill in Framingham

results.description:
Dear Fellow Bookclub Members,

This is the 2nd place winner of our last poll.  Please see the title and the description below.

Black Feminist Thought: Knowledge, Consciousness, and the Politics of Empowerment 


In spite of the double burden of racial and gender discrimination, African-American women have developed a rich intellectual tradition that is not widely known. In Black Feminist Thought, originally published in 1990, Patricia Hill Collins set out to explore the words and ideas of Black feminist intellectuals and writers, both within the academy and without. Here Collins provides an interpretive framework for the work of such prominent Black feminist thinkers as Angela Davis, bell hooks, Alice Walker, and Audre Lorde. Drawing from fiction, poetry, music and oral history, the result is a superbly crafted and revolutionary book that provided the first synthetic overview of Black feminist thought and its canon.
results.name: Lets Read and Discuss:  Black Feminist Thought....(long title see description)

results.description:
We'll hold our traditional Solstice celebration luncheon for the secular community again at the Phillips Brooks House in Harvard Yard, catered once again with a wonderful buffet meal, and followed by a talk on "Is Secularism Dying in Turkey and India?"

We'll have an Indian buffet lunch brought in (from the India Pavilion Restaurant in Central Square) with vegetarian and meat selections starting at 12:30 pm, for a cost of $11 per person, cash or check.  There will also be soft drinks, coffee and desserts provided.

DUE TO THE NEED TO PREORDER FOOD, PRE-REGISTRATION RSVP IS REQUIRED BY EMAIL OR PHONE, ALSO!!!! Please email [masked] before Friday 6/12 at 10 am --when you are sure you are coming, EVEN IF YOU ALREADY checked RSVP on this Meetup site! You may also call and leave a message at[masked]/9285

Our speaker at 1:30 pm will be one of our members, Professor Mark Lindley, who has just returned from a year of teaching at several Indian Universities. Although he is currently focusing on the field of Ecological Economics, he is very well versed in Indian history and political thought. He is the author, with Lavanam, of the book "Gandhi As We Knew Him", which is now in its 2nd Edition. About a decade ago he taught for 2 years in Turkish Universities, so is knowledgeable about the Turkish Social and Political arena. Both the Indian and Turkish Constitutions are adamantly secular. Recent developments clearly indicate that serious encroachments are occurring as religions gain more political currency and intrude more deeply into the life of these two societies. Will these usurpations eventually become so pervasive  that the secularity of these societies will be demolished? Mark will illuminate the situations for us.


Please MARK YOUR CALENDARS for this traditional community event, which is open to all (RSVP via email or phone required however). 

Celebrate the arrival of North American summer with us as we reach the solstice of another year!

________

Parking will be available in the Littauer Library Lot of Harvard University near the Science Center (Enter the Dworkin Science Quadrangle from Oxford St. and proceed to the end of the road to the parking area near the Science Center behind Littauer Library. If nervous, leave a note in your dashboard that you are at the Humanist event at PBH.)
results.name: Solstice Luncheon/Mark Lindley on "Is Secularism Dying in India and Turkey?"

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php

results.description:
June 13th @ 2:00 Harvard Museum of Natural History
The Wildlife of Brazil’s Pantanal:
A fascinating talk and photo presentation by Ossian Lindholm. Followed by a photo walk of Harvard Square Come experience the wondrous biodiversity of the Pantanal through they eyes of acclaimed South American nature photographer and environmentalist OssianLindholm. Ossian will share his captivating images of the world’s last great wildernesses, the largest contiguous wetland on the planet and South America’s primary wildlife sanctuary, declared a World Heritage Site and Biosphere Reserve by UNESCO. Through his engaging photos, Ossian will share his knowledge of the Pantanal's incredible biodiversity which includes almost 700 bird species, 100 different types of mammals, hundreds of fish and scores of reptile and amphibian species. This wildlife photography talk will bring you up close into his special encounters with tapirs, giant anteaters, caiman, capybaras, howler monkeys, giant river otters, the Hyacinth Macaw and finally the moment by moment tracking of elusive jaguar, the largest cat in the world and symbol what nature conservation tourism can achieve.
results.name: The Wildlife of Brazil’s Pantanal:  A photo presentation by Ossian Lindholm

results.description:
Notes from the first planning meeting on May 3, 2015:

Present at the meeting were: Daphne, Cyre, Tchad, Tasha and Thornton.

Southeast Asia is calling and the Onyx-birds have answered the call!

Round-trip tickets --> check

Passport --> check

Visa…wait a minute, NO VISA required for US or Jamaican citizens which makes this trip all the sweeter!!!

Better yet, Singapore is celebrating the BIG Five-Oh with a full year of activities to commemorate its 50 years of independence from the Malaysian Federation and forming its own sovereign republic on 9 August1965: https://www.singapore50.sg/SG50/WhatsOn.aspx

October 4, through October 13, 2015 are the official travel dates for this Southeast Asia trek. Not all Onyx-birds will be traveling at the same time, so there is flexibility to join during a portion or the entire time frame as your budget and vacation time allows.

To date, there are five confirmed travelers who have purchased round trip air fare:

Daphne, Tonya, Kenya, Crye and TChad

These members purchased round-trip fares from Boston to Singapore with an extended (18 hour) lay-over in Hong Kong on the return flight to Boston. For travelers and potential travelers that are interested in extending your stay in Hong Kong via the layover, it is easy and affordable. I was able to contact my air carrier, Cathay Pacific, and extend my stay in Hong Kong by two days for only $100 USD.

Thornton highly recommends including/extending your stay in this world class city of the orient as it will be well worth your while.

There are other destinations within the region that members have expressed interest in visiting. Bali appears to be topping the regional excursion list; and with Bali being a quick 2.5 hour flight from Singapore, it’s easy to see why. A full-list of excursions members plan to take are:

Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon) - Tonya
Manila – Tonya
Shanghai - Tonya
Bali – Daphne, Thornton, TChad
Hong Kong – Daphne, Tonya, Kenya, Cyre, TChad, Thornton.

As interest and confirmed travelers continue to grow for this excursion, so will the itinerary. Members have already expressed interest in:

Dance classes

Food Classes

Walking cultural tour (Viator)

Tai Chi/QiGong

Night Life and exploring Sentosa Island in Singapore

Our next meeting will focus on a central location for lodging, room sharing, excursions (who/what/when/where/how) and associated costs/budget.

Looking forward to seeing you all at the next meeting!

Daphne
results.name: Second Planning Meeting for Singapore & Hong Kong, @ Grove Hall Library, June 13

results.description:
Summer is here and the warmer weather has inspired us to have a health and wellness party! It's been a cruel Winter and it's time for a party!  Don't you think?

Let's mix and mingle and share our stories on what we are doing and what we still need to do to become our healthiest selves. 

Marceline, a physical therapist, will be on hand to give out free chair massages. CHAIR MASSAGES, PEOPLE!!!! There will be games indoors and out, and I’ll have an array of superfood nutritional samples, light refreshments and goodie bags!


As a family, we have been working towards transforming our health, bodies and mindsets. We'll share our journey because support systems have been a big part of our transformations, so let's get together to have fun, get to know each other and be pampered (CHAIR MASSAGES!!!)! 

The more the merrier, so bring friends.


CHAIR MASSAGES, PEOPLE!!!!
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Moody St from Route 9 West just after The Mall
results.name: Health and Wellness Party!

results.description:
Open since 1999 Organic Garden Cafe is the premier raw vegan restaurant in New England! COMPLEMENTARY TABLE APPETIZERS are provided to the group every 2nd Saturday monthly from 4-5:30pm! The menu offers a wide range of choices to delight your appetite including: juices, smoothies, soups, nori-rolls, spring rolls, pad thai, nachos, salads, pizza, burgers, pasta, tacos, gourmet daily specials, and deserts! www.organicgardencafe.com

Directions from Rte. 128 (including Boston Rte. 93N to Rte 128): Follow Rte 128 North. When Rte 128 North splits to the left from Rte 95, be sure to stay on Rte. 128 "North to Gloucester". Follow Rte 128 to Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right. Note: After Rte. 95 North and Rte. 128 split (north of Rte. 93) the numbering system for exits changes and exit numbers begin decreasing.

Directions from Boston via Rte. 1 [see above for Rte 93N Directions]: Take Rte. 1 North over the the Tobin Bridge. Follow until you see signs for Rte. 128 Gloucester and Rte. 95 North and take that exit. Bear left to take Rte. 128 North and stay on Rte 128 until Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right.

Directions from Salem: Go over the bridge from Salem to Beverly on Rte. 1A. Just after the bridge bear right onto Cabot St. Travel for 1 1/2 miles till you see Cabot Cinema and Organic Garden on the left.

Commuter Rail:
Newburyport/Rockport Line

results.description:
Radically enliven your sexuality and dive deep into the heart of your wild erotic nature.

ISTA is a transmission of the life force, clothed in love and expressing creatively in the world. ISTA is part of a global transformational movement where human consciousness is being opened to its source as love and harmoniously integrating with other sentient kingdoms and dimensions. In particular ISTA works with spirituality and sexuality as two expressions of the life force. Our vision is a world where humans have a peaceful, delightful, shameless, fearless and loving relationship with their own bodies, sexuality, emotions, hearts, minds and spirit.

ISTA is a modern synthesis of: 
a) a spiritual transmission - a satsang of being 
b) a mystery school where the Temple Arts are taught 
c) a new era business and creative community who are networked together globally and sharing resources in innovative ways.

ISTA collaborates with many groups, organizations, and communities in many locations around the world. Collaborations include International Goddess Congress, OSHO Communities, Tantra, Meditation, and Yoga Schools, Mystery Schools, Madonna Ministry International, and more!

Through a superb synthesis of neurological rewiring, ancient tantric practice, and shamanism, we will activate the powerful life force that is dwelling in your body. In the safety of our temple you will:


• Claim your erotic birthright to passion and pleasure

• Release fear, guilt and shame around sexuality

• Learn incredible tools and information that will enable you to use creative energy for regeneration, manifestation, healing and spiritual transformation

If you want to know if you are ready for this level of personal work or you know you are ready come join us to:


• Get a sneak peak at what ISTA offers around the world and right here in Massachusetts! 

• Hear first accounts from those in our community who have participated in an ISTA training (and we're just back from a fabulous weekend in Montreal, too!)

• Ask questions about this transformational, love-filled, live giving training 

ISTA: International School of Temple Arts is committed to raising consciousness & sexuality education across the globe to grow community, provide conferences, events, and trainings to individuals, practitioners and teachers, and to provide business tools and collaborations to support the emergence of the Temple Arts around the world.

ISTA was Founded in 2007 as a non-profit educational organization and is co-operated by a consortium of leaders in the many Sacred Temple Arts. What started as gatherings of teachers and practitioners quickly evolved into ISTA, a consortium of empowered individuals representing every continent, to became a vehicle that connects experts from around the globe and now operates worldwide in over 30 countries.

“Love is your birthright, you need to do nothing to prove yourself or earn love. You just need to live love.”—wkm.

-Please note that this event has been promoted in multiple places. We expect at least 20 people there.  It will be experiential and you will enjoy it.

In addition, this event will be promoting the week long ISTA I workshop in July. We will be offering a $200 discount to people who sign up for that.

You will benefit from the exercises in this event regardless of whether you sign up for the ISTA I workshop.
results.how_to_find_us: Parking on the street.
results.name: Spiritual Sexual Shamanic Experience - A No Cost Teaser

We're getting together to finalize our travel and lodging plans to Montreal during their Jazz Festival and Carnival over the July 4th weekend.

We will also discuss expectations, things to do and figure out roommates.

PLEASE MAKE EVERY EFFORT TO ATTEND AND ARRIVE AT 4PM

Check out this link for details and/or to RSVP, http://www.meetup.com/BostonOnyxbirds/events/222013508/

There is FREE parking next to the Grove Hall Library 41 Geneva Avenue Dorchester 02121 (617)[masked]

Montreal Trip Planning Meetup Recap

Trip Dates July 2 – 6, 2015

Planning Date: Saturday May 16, 2015

Time: 3PM – 5PM

Location: Grove Hall Library Children's Activities Room 41 Geneva Avenue Dorchester 02121

Our main objectives were to determine travel dates, arrange carpools and lodging

---------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------

Fifth Car after ?? – Aaron (car owner)

--------------------------------------------------------------

Marie-Claire, Aliyah, Tonia and Crystal are flexible and can leave Montreal either Sunday July 5th or Monday July 6th

Tbird is flying and Jeronica is thinking about flying as well.

Olu if he goes will drive his own car leaving Boston on Thursday July 2nd and Montreal on Sunday July 5th after 4PM

Adusu and Rochelle will arrange their own travel and lodging

Montreal ACCOMADATIONS central location is Place de Artes sample address is Hyatt Downtown address: 1255 Rue Jeanne-Mance, Montréal, QC H5B 1E5, Canada

COMMUNICATION

results.description:
Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away? Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process? Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome. Do you have a cribbage board? If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before? The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham. Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

HOW TO GET THERE

Panera Bread is located at 1100 Lexington Street in Waltham -- in the Shaw's plaza near the corner of Lexington Street and Trapelo Road. Ample parking. Web site: http://www.panera-bos...
results.name: Fun & Games in Waltham, MA

results.description:
Host Duncan will be leaving at 8:00 to the reggae event --description below-- there's no cover. Accompany me as a group if you're interested. Then we leave the reggae at 9 (unless you want to stay) to get to the dancing: 
http://www.meetup.com/SocialFun/events/222715178/

A recent discovery of Social Fun (us), we are getting a lot of imitation Meetup.com event groups scheduling here because of the outcry of enthusiasm about this venue. Manager Frank is usually there, he is a very big guy, but a honey pie with the heart of a teddy bear.

Carrie Nation on Beacon Hill opened last year.
Popular with Meetups, it's named after the infamous Carrie Nation, the key founder of  Prohibition.

This is a rolling come and go as you can event. Some folks come just for a drink, others hang out and chat for a few hours. There's good food here too but ordering food is optional.

Please bring cash & pay as you go! MBTA to Park St. (Red line), then a pretty short walk 2 blocks up the hill.

Look forward to seeing you again!


AFTER PARTY is at STERLINGS 60 State Street BOSTON, MA (2nd Level Patio Bar in Daniel Hall...faces Congress Street) FREE BOB MARLEY Tribute BAND, DUPPY CONQUERORS 7 to 10 PM Tonight!! Look for Lauren there.

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
The staff of a Korean War field hospital use humor and hijinks to keep their sanity in the face of the horror of war.

Director:  Robert AltmanWriters:  Richard Hooker (from the novel by),  Ring Lardner Jr. (screenplay)Stars:  Donald Sutherland,  Elliott Gould,  Tom Skerritt | IMDB:  7.8

FOUR STARS:  ROGER EBERT:

"Most comedies want us to laugh at things that aren't really funny; in this one we laugh precisely because they're not funny. We laugh, that we may not cry.

But none of this philosophy comes close to the insane logic of "MASH," which is achieved through a peculiar marriage of cinematography, acting, directing, and writing. The movie depends upon timing and tone to be funny. I had an opportunity to read the original script, and I found it uninteresting. It would have been a failure, if it had been directed like most comedies; but Ring Lardner, Jr., wrote it, I suspect, for exactly the approach Robert Altman used in his direction, and so the angle of a glance or the timing of a pause is funnier than any number of conventional gag lines."

We can also meet upstairs in the lobby following the screening, if we want to go somewhere for a drink and another discussion of all things Robert Altman

See you at the Robert Altman Festival,

John
results.how_to_find_us: We can gather at the Grafton Street Pub at 5:00 for patio fuel and discussion of Robert Altman

results.description:
Immerse yourself in a potent field of transformation.


The Integrative Chakra Breath Journey™ is a powerful bio-energetic process that will open up energy flow and oxygen circulation throughout your whole body. Release blocked energy and pent-up emotions through a special breath technique that guides you to loop your breath through all of your chakras. Fill your body to capacity with radiant energy. Come in contact with your Source of life and power. The active stage of the meditation is followed by a silent stage, in which you bask in a vast field of peace and relaxation. The silence you experience after working with breath is profound and clear. Through this process you will experience renewed aliveness and freedom.

Each Chakra stores the collection of our core beliefs, emotions and experiences in correlation to seven fundamental themes in our life: survival, creativity, power, love, self-expression, wisdom, and divine connection.


Through this dynamic meditation you will:


♦ De-Stress!

♦ Revitalize!

♦ Embody your Personal Power!

♦ Clear and balance each vital energy center

♦ Strengthen your immune system

♦ Harness your power of manifestation

♦ Feel energized, relaxed and happy

♦ Experience deep relaxation and peace


No previous experience necessary. Beginners welcome! Wear loose, comfortable clothing. Mats will be provided. Bring a water bottle.


Student Raves:

“Always different every time around, but what is the same is that it is always profound and deep...

Such wonderful energy raised and feelings moved. When we started to merge voices, it was truly magical. What a great gathering of souls. I came in with a somber heart, but left with a beautiful smile inside and out.” – Laurie A


“This class was very healing and integrating for me. The more I practice the Integrative Chakra Breath Journey, the better I feel.

I particularly enjoyed setting the intention to manifest something in my life while I was in a very high energized and altered state of being.” - BJ


“Deep, profound release and synergy amongst the group... again... it's consistent 5 stars for me!” – Steve C
results.name: Integrative Chakra Breath Journey

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58

C'mon dancers! Let's take a running...or rather...DANCING leap into summer at our Jumpin' June Dance Party!

Intro Group Lesson begins at 8:00pm (optional, but a wonderful way to break the ice with fellow dancers!)
Party begins at 8:30pm

$5 per person

Join the studio as we continue our Second Saturday Social Series: our monthly ballroom dance socials held on the 2nd Saturday of every month. All experience levels and ages welcome, and no partner required! Smart-casual to Elegant attire encouraged.

Check out our FAQ's below for more info.

Star Dance School
323 Washington Street
Brighton, MA
[masked]
[masked]

StarDanceSchool.com

----------------------------------------------------------------
Ballroom Dance Social FAQ's:

What is a “Ballroom Social”?
A ballroom social is a dance party featuring ballroom dance styles. Music is played for Standard and Smooth styles such as waltz, foxtrot, and tango as well as Latin and Rhythm styles including salsa, rumba, cha-cha, and the like. At Star Dance School Socials an optional 30 minute group dance lesson kicks off the evening as well!

What on earth should I wear?!
Smart-casual to elegant attire is encouraged, but most importantly wear clothing you can move around in comfortably. If you do not have ballroom shoes often a light weight dress shoe will do the trick. *Note: Please avoid sneakers or metal spike-heel shoes as they can damage our floor. Thank you for your understanding!*

Do I need a partner?
Partners are welcome, but not required to enjoy a night out on the town with us! Social dancing is a fantastic way to make new friends and we encourage dancers to rotate partners in order to meet new people.

Do I need prior dance experience?
Whether it is your first time dancing or you have years of ballroom under your belt, all levels are welcome to attend our socials!

results.description:
Folks, weather forecast is so-so and I didn't get the permit for Truro yet, 2-3 hours is too much driving for a chance to get clouded in.


We will kick off the 2015 season for Milky Way and Astro-landscape photography with our first shoot at Halibut Point State Park, which is a fairly dark location looking east over the ocean. HPSP is a an old quarry, which makes for a good foreground.


We will *briefly* review settings, shooting options and approaches, but if you have not done much Milky Way shooting, it is highly recommended that you attend the free lecture scheduled for earlier this month. Preference will be given for attendees of that workshop.


Sunset is 8:22, but it doesn't get dark until 9, hence. the late meetup time. The Milky Way will come over the horizon at that time, but best shooting will be between 10 and midnight or later, so this is a late night event. The moon will be out of the way all night. Bring a sleeping bag / mat, hot and cold drinks, snacks and bug spray.


Important: please bring a DIM light to check your settings. Please do NOT use large or bright flashlights, I will give you a hard time if you do. The human eye needs 30 minutes to adjust to darkness. Every time you use a flashlight, you will blind yourself and, more importantly, blind others and show up in other people's shots. This is important, please use a star gazer approach. Very small, DIM, red lights work best. Absolutely no headlamps allowed!


The Celestron Astro Night Vision light is perfect, you can regulate the brightness all the way down to almost invisible to others. I highly recommend that you get this light for all your night photo activities. 

This little gem is perfect: very small key chain light, always handy and as dim as it gets. You can set it to be very dim (press and hold until it JUST comes on) or full fledged red light. Not cheap, but a perfect solution.

A very cheap solution is this 10-pack for $3.


You can read more about dim lights here.


As always, this event is heavily weather dependent, if forecast degrades any further instead of improving, it will likely be rescheduled.

This is what the Milky Way will look like at 10 pm, the MW will arch from south to north and will give us a nice opportunity for a landscape panorama.

Here are some shots of Halibut park:

Parking is very limited. Do not park in the official parking lot or along the street, you may be locked in, ticketed or towed. Last time they did not lock the lot, but you are on your own if they do. I marked available parking in the image below, that house was unoccupied and a resident told us we can park there.
results.name: Milky Way Season kick-off: Halibut Point State Park

results.description:
Carl's Diner in Oxford MA

We are off to bacon heaven again!  This is the spot where a grill cheese has about 10 pieces of bacon in it!

 Don't let the exterior fool you. Inside you'll find an original 1920 s style dining car that has been in this location since World War II. Complete with dark quartersawn oak panels and trim, nostalgia is written all over. The portions are enormous and the food is the home style cooking that you would expect from a local landmark. Clearly the local dining hangout, it comes with a whole cast of characters and the humorous off color banter that ensues. Carl's Diner will give you a lot more to take home with that pound plus doggie bag.

Road Captain:  Deeg

Meeting Location Dunkin Donuts Randolph

Meeting time:  8 am

KSU: 830 am

results.description:
Sure we could take the easy way that we've done before, but where's the fun in that? This hike will feature the Great Gulf Wilderness, two of the steepest trails out of the Gulf (Wamsutta and Chandler Brook), and the Alpine Garden which if the timing works out will be in full bloom.

This hike is dependent on weather and may be reschedule to Sunday if the weather is more cooperative. The decision will be made by Friday morning if Saturday is still a go or not.

If you're looking to bag a peak this hike isn't for you. If you like wild beautiful trails, steep climbs, wild flowers, rivers, waterfalls, and cascades, and expansive views then this may be for you.

Starting from the Great Gulf Trailhead we'll follow the trail along the river which is one of my favorite sections of trail in the Whites. We'll pass the Bluff,  cross the AT and two rivers, pass Clam Rock, and Chandler Brook trail. This will be an relatively easy 1800' over 4.5 miles to the much more difficult Wamsutta Trail which takes us up 2200' in 1.7 miles. That's about as steep as the trails get in the Whites. This trail is described as steep and rough but wild and beautiful. It includes several scrambles including one difficult scramble up a chimney.


The trail ends at the auto road from which we'll hike out and back on the Alpine Garden trail past Huntington Ravine to Lion's Head. Back at the road we'll hike down the winter cutoff of the auto road to Chandler Brook Trail. Octopus. This is another steep trail with 1300' of descent over 0.9 miles. It follows the brook which it crosses several times and passes many cascades and waterfalls returning us to the Great Gulf Trail and back to the cars in another 3.9 miles.


Totals: 15.0 mi, 4700' of elevation gain, 9:55 book time

Level: Advanced

Since this an advanced hike I will be screening participants closely to ascertain their experience and that they are prepared for what they are signing up for.

I'd like to keep a moderate pace [masked] mph average) but we'll hike as a group and stay together. You should be equipped for a 3 season day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing for a variety of temperatures (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, hat, and basic first aid supplies. See the Ten Essentials and the Three Season day Hike List as a reference.

DISCLAIMER


============

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: Advanced: Alpine Garden via Great Gulf

results.description:
Join Argentinian master nature photographer Ossian Lindholm for a photo walk of Ipswich River, one of Mass Audubon’s largest sanctuaries offering more than 12 miles of interconnecting trails that invite you to explore the forests, meadows, and wetlands.

We will photograph for a few hours. We will point out the abundant wildlife

Some of the subjects we hope to see and photograph include frogs, painted turtles, great blue herons, bluebirds, beavers, dragonflies, damselflies, black capped chickadees and tufted titmouse eat seeds out of you hand.

The drumlin and esker, landscape features created by a glacier 15,000 years ago. Huge rocks and exotic trees and shrubs that were part of a former arboretum provide an adventurous walk along the Rockery Trail.

Directions:
From Boston and the south: Take Rt I-95 north to exit 50 and follow Rt 1 north. At the junction of Rt 1 and Rt 97, turn right onto Rt 97 south (toward Beverly and Danvers). Follow Rt 97 south and take the third left onto Perkins Row. Follow Perkins Row for 1 mile, and the sanctuary is on the right.

From the north: Take Rt I-95 south to exit 53A and follow Rt 97 south. At the junction of Rt 1 and Rt 97 in Topsfield, stay on Rt 97 south and take the third left onto Perkins Row. Follow Perkins Row for 1 mile, and the sanctuary is on the right.

Admission:
Mass Audubon Members FREE $4 for nonmember Address:
87 Perkins Row
Topsfield, MA 01983
[masked]
[masked]
http://www.massaudubon.org/Nature_Connection/Sanctuaries/Ipswich_River/index.php

There will be two rides - one 5 miler for those who want an easy, fun ride and a 25 miler for those who want to burn off  more calories so can have a second helping of pie that night! Both rides will have escort riders so you don't ever have to worry about getting lost or going too slow. Just hope on your bike and enjoy the ride!!


Here is the route for the 25 miler. Lots of beautiful trees, estates and hills! Plenty of great open road for those who want to go further.

Here's a link to the interactive map of the ride (you can also print the map and a cue sheet from here as well as export to a GPS format):

http://ridewithgps.com/routes/8476987

Below is the five mile ride. It is 2.8 miles out with a turn around and rest stop at the fabulous Powisset Farm in Dover and 2.8 miles back of easy, fun biking though mostly Hale and Trustees beautiful park land. We can even add another mile of road in the lovely Hale reservation for those who want a little more!


Here is a link to the map for this ride:

http://ridewithgps.com/routes/8468841

results.description:
In 1916, this 114-acre hillside property attracted Atlantic Monthly editor and publisher Ellery Sedgwick and his wife for its lovely views of the rural North Shore. But Mabel Cabot Sedgwick, an accomplished gardener and horticulturist, had more ambitious – and aesthetic – ideas. As the couple formulated plans for the elegant Federal-style home that would become their summer retreat, Mabel Sedgwick also set about designing gardens and landscape amenities that are renowned a century later. After her death in 1937, her vision was sustained and expanded by the second Mrs. Sedgwick, the former Marjorie Russell, a rare plants specialist, who added new and rare species of trees and shrubs to the estate, some introduced by the Arnold Arboretum in Jamaica Plain.

The gardens are laid out in a series of separate garden “rooms” surrounding the handsome, Federal-style, brick house. Each “room” is distinct in its own way, accented by ornaments and statuary. Today, the gardens retain the “Garden for Living”–style with integrated outdoor rooms, mature plantings that blend into the surrounding woodlands, and a spirit of innovation in horticulture.

The gardens are flanked on all sides by more than 100 acres of woodland as well as an apple orchard, meadow, children’s garden, and agricultural fields, including a 2-acre organic vegetable farm run by The Food Project as a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) project.


A popular 1.2-mile main loop trail – great for families – passes through quintessentially New England woodlands dotted by vernal pools and imposing boulders.


We will start our walk at 10:00, so if you are running late, please catch up!


Directions


From Rt. 128 Exit 18, take Rt. 22 North 1 mi. Bear left at split in road and continue for 0.2 mi. on Essex Street to entrance on left (street number 572 is on the brick pillars). Parking area (50 cars) is up the driveway on left.

Walking
Trail map


Meet At
Meet in the parking lot.


Fees and Admission
 No fees.

If you need to reach me to locate us: 
Call me on my cell:[masked]-4624.

Afterwards many of us will walk a few blocks to SOWA (South of Washington) Markets and peruse among the 70+ vendors of fresh fruits & veggies, gourmet condiments, fresh flowers, quality crafts & clothes and the antiques market. In addition, the food trucks will be there!

A smile is guaranteed for all.

results.description:
Did you know there is still snow in Somerville? 


Join the Boston Volunteers at Draw 7 Park. Draw 7 Park served as a snow farm over the winter and still has the remnants from this winter’s record-breaking storm. While the snow will eventually melt, the large amount of trash and debris left behind will not. Luckily, Groundwork Somerville is aiming to help with our brand new Cleaning & Greening Initiative! This new community-based volunteer program consists of monthly projects to improve public spaces around the city of Somerville. The 2015 Cleaning & 


We'll be doing a massive cleanup and debris removal in Draw 7 Park. 

A couple other popular groups will be joining us including: 

Don't you like to help people: Boston Volunteers

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like Adventure: BBoston Adventures

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We hope you can join us!

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

results.description:
Forecast shows nice weather for tomorrow. 


This ride is about 25 miles and runs through the towns of Lexington, Concord and Lincoln.  The Globe rates it as a top 10 Mass scenic ride.  Relatively flat except one large hill. 

Will try to keep roughly a 12-15 mile pace and be back in Lexington before 12:30.  Will stop on occasion to make sure we try to travel as a group and stop along the way at the Old North Bridge in Concord.  Optional lunch in Lexington to follow.

This is not a ride for the super competitive as we do stop for everyone but will ask you to turn around / bike on your own if you can't keep a 12-15 mile pace.  Also as a requirement for this ride I ask that you have a face picture so we can recognize you as we are a social group.

Lexington Center has a public parking lot adjacent to the bike path with free parking on Sunday


Things to bring:  Helmet, Water, Sun Tan lotion, Money for lunch after the ride.

 Rain cancels.

(also if anyone is interest we could have an option to meet at Alewife station at 9:15 which would add an additional 12 miles to the ride round trip.  Would leave at 9:20 and meet the group in lexington center by 10)

results.description:
This Commuter Rail accessible ride tours western Cape Ann. Despite the seaside glory of Rockport and Gloucester, the real nice biking and scenery is to be found in the laid-back western part of Cape Ann - in eastern Beverly, Hamilton, Ipswich, Essex, Manchester-by-the-Sea, and Wenham.  We will be stopping in Manchester-by-the-Sea for ice cream from Dusty's or quick food from Crosby's grocery store.

Make sure you bring a road bike.  A hybrid is a good bike for this ride too, if you are in good shape.  Sorry, no mountain bikes should be used on this all-road ride.


Route map on Ride with GPS: ridewithgps.com/routes/[masked]

Cue sheet: app.box.com/s/kbx08g5i5z0v2ggad8yi559jk8hv9l8r


For those who are arriving by train, there are some time contraints.  This means that in order to make it back in time you need to have an average speed on the road of 12 mph or faster, and a lunch no longer than 30 minutes. (This is a casual speed by the way, so it shouldn't be too hard for many people.) I will be arriving by train myself from Swampscott.  Departure time for this ride will actually be 10:20 not 10:15, but Meetup doesn't allow me to list an odd time for a start.

Getting there by the T: The Commuter Rail arrives at 10:09 AM at the North Beverly train station from Boston. The station is very close to the parking lot start behind Starbucks. Trains arrive at North Beverly at 1:15 to head toward Boston.
results.how_to_find_us: On Route 1A just north of North Beverly station
